<section><paragraph><sentence id="25859066/2">The community of <link synthetic="true"><target>'Malakeng</target><part>Malakeng</part></link> includes the villages of Ha 'Majane, Ha 'Motsi, Ha Daniel, Ha Hlelesi, Ha Jase, Ha Kanono, Ha Kholoanyane, Ha Khorong, Ha Lemonomono, Ha Letooane, Ha Likhama, Ha Makhaooane, Ha Makhasane, Ha Makoanyane, Ha Maliehe, Ha Motau, Ha Ntele, Ha Phatela, Ha Pitso, Ha Qaba, Ha Rabele, Ha Ralehoabali, Ha Ralipoli, Ha Ramakhakhe, Ha Ramosoeu, Ha Rantanyane, Ha Rantho, Ha Rapokane, Ha Setlakotlako, Ha Shololo, Ha Tebelo, Ha Tlhone, Ha Tohlang, Ha T?oeunyane, Ha Tsoinyane, Khilibiting, Lehlakaneng, Letlapeng (Malealea), Likhohloaneng, Lithabaneng, Lit?oeneng, Makhetheng, Makhomalong (Malealea), Makhoseng, Malere, Metsohlong, Mohlakeng, Ngoana-Khare, Pitseng, Sekhutlong, Sekiring, T?eea-Nku and Tutulung.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Lesotho Bureau of Statistics,<space/><link type="external" href="http://www.bos.gov.ls/Downloads.htm">Village List</link><space/>2006.</extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="30557864/0">In two spatial and one time dimensions,<space/><link><target>general relativity</target></link><space/>turns out to have no propagating gravitational degrees of freedom.</sentence> <sentence id="30557864/1">In fact, it can be shown that in a vacuum, spacetime will always be locally flat (or<space/><link><target>de Sitter space</target><part>de Sitter</part></link><space/>or<space/><link><target>anti de Sitter space</target><part>anti de Sitter</part></link><space/>depending upon the<space/><link><target>cosmological constant</target></link>).</sentence> <sentence id="30557864/2">This makes<space/><bold>(2+1)-dimensional topological gravity</bold><space/>a<space/><link><target>topological quantum field theory</target><part>topological theory</part></link><space/>with no gravitational local degrees of freedom.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="30557864/3"><link><target>Edward Witten</target></link><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite journal">
<param name="last">Witten</param>
<param name="first">Edward</param>
<param name="authorlink">Edward Witten</param>
<param name="date">19 Dec 1988</param>
<param name="title">(2+1)-Dimensional Gravity as an Exactly Soluble System</param>
<param name="journal"><link><target>Nuclear Physics B</target></link></param>
<param name="volume">311</param>
<param name="issue">1</param>
<param name="pages">46&ndash;78</param>
<param name="doi">10.1016/0550-3213(88)90143-5</param>
<param name="bibcode">1988NuPhB.311...46W</param>
</template><template name="cite journal">
<param name="last">Witten</param>
<param name="first">Edward</param>
<param name="authorlink">Edward Witten</param>
<param name="date">19 Dec 1988</param>
<param name="title">(2+1)-Dimensional Gravity as an Exactly Soluble System</param>
<param name="journal"><link><target>Nuclear Physics B</target></link></param>
<param name="volume">311</param>
<param name="issue">1</param>
<param name="pages">46&ndash;78</param>
<param name="doi">10.1016/0550-3213(88)90143-5</param>
<param name="bibcode">1988NuPhB.311...46W</param>
</template></extension><space/>has argued this is equivalent to a<space/><link><target>Chern-Simons theory</target></link><space/>with the gauge group<space/><extension extension_name="math">SO(2,2)</extension><space/>for a negative cosmological constant, and<space/><extension extension_name="math">SO(3,1)</extension><space/>for a positive one, which can be exactly solved, making this a<space/><link><target>toy model</target></link><space/>for<space/><link><target>quantum gravity</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="30557864/4">The<space/><link><target>Killing form</target></link><space/>involves the<space/><link><target>Hodge dual</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="30557864/5"><link synthetic="true"><target>Edward Witten</target><part>Witten</part></link> later changed his mind,<extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite arxiv">
<param name="last">Witten</param>
<param name="first">Edward</param>
<param name="authorlink">Edward Witten</param>
<param name="date">22 June 2007</param>
<param name="title">Three-Dimensional Gravity Reconsidered</param>
<param name="eprint">0706.3359</param>
</template><template name="cite arxiv">
<param name="last">Witten</param>
<param name="first">Edward</param>
<param name="authorlink">Edward Witten</param>
<param name="date">22 June 2007</param>
<param name="title">Three-Dimensional Gravity Reconsidered</param>
<param name="eprint">0706.3359</param>
</template></extension><space/>and argued that nonperturbatively 2+1D topological gravity differs from <link synthetic="true"><target>Chern-Simons theory</target><part>Chern-Simons</part></link> because the<space/><link><target>functional measure</target></link><space/>is only over nonsingular<space/><link><target>vielbein</target><trail>s</trail></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="30557864/6">He suggested the<space/><link><target>AdS/CFT correspondence</target><part>CFT dual</part></link><space/>is a Monster conformal field theory, and computed the entropy of<space/><link><target>BTZ black hole</target><trail>s</trail></link>.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<param name="balsrc"><link type="external" href="http://www.hornady.com/story.php?s=787">338 Marlin Express LEVERevolution at Hornady web site</link><space/>&amp;<space/><link type="external" href="http://www.midwayusa.com/browse/BrowseProducts.aspx?tabid=3&amp;categoryid=20480&amp;categorystring=653***690***">MidwayUSA</link></param>
</template></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="21628145/0">The<space/><bold>.338 <link synthetic="true"><target>.338 Marlin Express</target><part>Marlin Express</part></link></bold><space/>is a new cartridge developed by<space/><link><target>Marlin Firearms</target></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Hornady</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/1">It is based on the<space/><link><target>.376 Steyr</target></link><space/>with a goal to duplicate the venerable<space/><link><target>.30-06 Springfield</target></link>'s performance in a cartridge compatible with lever-action firearms.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/2">The cartridge uses a slightly shorter,<space/><link><target>Rim (firearms)</target><part>rimmed</part></link><space/>case to function in<space/><link><target>lever action</target></link><space/>rifles with tubular<space/><link><target>magazine (firearms)</target><part>magazines</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/3">As introduced in <link synthetic="true"><target>Hornady</target><part>Hornady's</part></link> LEVERevolution line of cartridges, it follows the design logic of the<space/><link><target>.308 Marlin Express</target></link><space/>which preceded it.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/4">The .338MX fires heavier .338 caliber bullets than the<space/><link><target>.308 Marlin Express</target></link><space/>at roughly the same velocity.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/5">It is chambered in <link synthetic="true"><target>Marlin Model 336</target><part>Marlin's Model</part></link> 338MX and 338MXLR rifles using the<space/><link><target>Marlin Model 336</target></link><space/>action.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://www.marlinfirearms.com/Firearms/308MarlinExpress/default.aspx">308 Marlin Express at Marlin web site</link></extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="21628145/6">Whereas the<space/><link><target>.308 Marlin Express</target></link><space/>began by modifying the<space/><link><target>.307 Winchester</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Hornady</target></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Marlin Firearms</target><part>Marlin</part></link><space/>engineers started with a previous collaboration between <link synthetic="true"><target>Hornady</target></link> and the Austrian arms maker<space/><link><target>Steyr Mannlicher</target><part>Steyr</part></link>, the<space/><link><target>.376 Steyr</target></link>, when designing the .338 <link synthetic="true"><target>.338 Marlin Express</target><part>Marlin Express</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/7">The case of the<space/><link><target>.376 Steyr</target></link><space/>was given a thicker web for added strength, then necked down to .338.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/8">The .308 <link synthetic="true"><target>.338 Marlin Express</target><part>Marlin Express</part></link>, on the other hand, was made with a thinner web than its parent case, the .307 <link synthetic="true"><target>.307 Winchester</target><part>Winchester</part></link>, for additional capacity.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/9">Although the thicker case webbing reduced capacity, new powders allow the .338 <link synthetic="true"><target>.338 Marlin Express</target><part>Marlin Express</part></link> to achieve velocities similar to the<space/><link><target>.338 Federal</target></link><space/>with significantly lower pressures.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/10"><link synthetic="true"><target>Hornady</target></link> engineers then looked to the projectile for the new cartridge.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/11">They settled on the 200-grain .338 projectile from their<space/><link><target>.338 Winchester Magnum</target></link><space/>line.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/12">The existing bullet was remade with a thinner jacket in order to promote expansion and upset at longer ranges.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/13">This 200-grain .338" projectile is able to impart significantly more energy than the 160&nbsp;gr projectile used in the .308 <link synthetic="true"><target>.338 Marlin Express</target><part>Marlin Express</part></link>, despite similar muzzle velocities.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/14">Further, the projectile's high<space/><link><target>ballistic coefficient</target></link><space/>allows the .338 <link synthetic="true"><target>.338 Marlin Express</target><part>Marlin Express</part></link> to maintain velocity to greater distances than big bore lever cartridges such as<space/><link><target>.45-70</target></link>,<space/><link><target>.444 Marlin</target></link>, or even the high performance<space/><link><target>.450 Marlin</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/15">Although the heavy bullet weight of these cartridges allow them more muzzle energy, the ballistic advantage of the .338 <link synthetic="true"><target>.338 Marlin Express</target><part>Marlin Express's</part></link> projectile begins to show beyond 100 yds.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/16">After that point the .338 <link synthetic="true"><target>.338 Marlin Express</target><part>Marlin Express's</part></link> projectile retains more energy than even the .450 <link synthetic="true"><target>Marlin Firearms</target><part>Marlin</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/17">Like the .308 <link synthetic="true"><target>.338 Marlin Express</target><part>Marlin Express</part></link>, the .338 <link synthetic="true"><target>.338 Marlin Express</target><part>Marlin Express</part></link> was designed to be a relatively flat shooting cartridge, taking advantage of the relatively high Bc bullets <link synthetic="true"><target>Hornady</target></link> designed for the rounds.</sentence> <sentence id="21628145/18">Its trajectory is similar to the<space/><link><target>.30-06 Springfield</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://www.rifleshootermag.com/ammunition/RS_338_122008WO/">"All Aboard the .338 Marlin Express" article in ''Peterson's Rifle Shooter Magazine''</link></extension></paragraph></section>

The .338 .338 Marlin ExpressMarlin Express was designed to produce performance similar to the.30-06 Springfield. This would give lever-action hunters improved performance over their.30-30 Winchesterrounds. The table below shows how the rounds compare. Note that reloading data for 200-grain (10 g) bullets for some of the cartridges is not available. Extensive loading data for the .338 .338 Marlin ExpressMarlin Express is not yet available. The powder used in the Hornady loading is also not yet commercially available as of Feb '09. This round was designed with an elastomer tip, so that the .338 projectile would be safe for use in thetubular magazinesoflever actionrifles. Traditional spitzer bullets are not compatible with thetubular magazines. This is due to the danger of the hard, pointed bullet-tip igniting thepercussion capprimerof the round in front of it under recoil impulse. The softer tip eliminates the hazards of stacking pointed rounds end to end in a tubular magazine..338 Marlin Express quick comparisonCartridgeBullet Weight (Grain (mass)gr)Muzzle velocity(ft/s)Muzzle energy(Foot-pound forceft-lbf)Ballistic coefficientBCVelocity (ft/s)/Energy (Foot-pound forceft-lbf) @ 400yds.338 .338 Marlin ExpressMarlin Express20025652922.4301820/1471.308 Marlin Express16026602513308 Marlin Express LEVERevolution at Hornady web site?1836/1197.30-30 Winchester16023001880the .30-30 Winchester by Chuck Hawks.30-06 Springfield20025422879MidwayUSA data for Lapua Ammunition .30-06 Springfield 200gr Soft Point ammunition.30-06 Springfield20026253061MidwayUSA data for Norma Ammunition .30-06 Springfield 200gr "Oryx Protected Point" soft point ammunition.376 Steyr(Parent Cartridge)21030114229

This load uses a polymer tipped hunting round similar to that of Hornady's .338 Marlin Express.30-06 Springfield200gr SP25422879.30-06 Springfield200gr OPP26253061.338 Federal210gr Nos Part26303226.325 WSM200gr Accubond CT29503866.338 Winchester Magnum200gr SP29503866.35 Remington200gr Lead Flat Nose20841929.348 Winchester200gr25302840.358 Winchester200gr SP25002776.35 Whelen200gr27983478.340 Weatherby Magnum200gr SP322146079.3x62mm9.3x62mm Mauser231 gr Oryx26003550

</template></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="1236209/1"><bold>.ke</bold><space/>is the<space/><link><target>Internet</target></link><space/><link><target>country code</target></link><space/><link><target>top-level domain</target></link><space/>(<link><target>ccTLD</target></link>) for<space/><link><target>Kenya</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="1236209/2">Second-level domains, under which domains are registered at the third level, are:</sentence></paragraph><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence id="1236209/3"><bold>.co.ke</bold><space/>- for Companies</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="1236209/4"><bold>.or.ke</bold><space/>- for Not-for-Profit-Making Organisations or NGO's</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="1236209/5"><bold>.ne.ke</bold><space/>- for Network Devices</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="1236209/6"><bold>.go.ke</bold><space/>- for Government Entities.</sentence> <sentence id="1236209/7">Requires Supporting Documents</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="1236209/8"><bold>.ac.ke</bold><space/>- for Institutions of Higher Education.</sentence> <sentence id="1236209/9">Requires Supporting Documents</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="1236209/10"><bold>.sc.ke</bold><space/>- for Lower and Middle Institutes of Learning.</sentence> <sentence id="1236209/11">Requires Supporting Documents</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="1236209/12"><bold>.me.ke</bold><space/>- for Personal names</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="1236209/13"><bold>.mobi.ke</bold><space/>- for Mobile content</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="1236209/14"><bold>.info.ke</bold><space/>- for Information</sentence></listitem></list><paragraph><sentence id="1236209/15">Details of these, and of the unusual delegation mechanism used by the .ke zone, can be found in some ccTLD analysis<extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://www.robert.net/ccTLD/KE</param>
<param name="title">KE ccTLD</param>
<param name="work">Robert Baskerville's ccTLD analysis data</param>
<param name="date">2008-01-01</param>
<param name="accessdate">2008-01-01</param>
</template><template name="cite web">

<param name="accessdate">2008-01-01</param>
</template></extension></sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph>1,2,4-Trimethylbenzene dissolved in<space/><sentence id="4547829/6"><link><target>mineral oil</target></link><space/>is used as a liquid<space/><link><target>scintillator</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="4547829/7">It is also used as a sterilizing agent and in the manufacture of dyes, perfumes, and resins.</sentence> <sentence id="4547829/8">Another major use is as a gasoline additive.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite web">

</template></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="4514062/0"><bold>1,2-<link synthetic="true"><target>1,2-Ethanedithiol</target><part>Ethanedithiol</part></link></bold><space/>is a colorless liquid with the formula C<xhtml:sub xmlns:xhtml="">2</xhtml:sub>H<xhtml:sub xmlns:xhtml="">4</xhtml:sub>(SH)<xhtml:sub xmlns:xhtml="">2</xhtml:sub>.</sentence> <sentence id="4514062/1">It has a very characteristic odor which is compared by many people to rotten cabbage.</sentence> <sentence id="4514062/2">It is a common building block in<space/><link><target>organic synthesis</target></link><space/>and an excellent ligand for metal ions.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph>1,2-Ethanedithiol is commercially available. <sentence id="4514062/3">It can be prepared by the action of<space/><link><target>1,2-Dibromoethane</target><part>1,2-dibromoethane</part></link><space/>on<space/><link><target>thiourea</target></link><space/>followed by<space/><link><target>hydrolysis</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="OrgSynth">
<param name="author">Speziale, A. J.</param>
<param name="title">Ethanedithiol</param>
<param name="collvol">4</param>
<param name="collvolpages">401</param>
<param name="year">1963</param>
<param name="prep">cv4p0401</param>
</template><template name="OrgSynth">
<param name="author">Speziale, A. J.</param>
<param name="title">Ethanedithiol</param>
<param name="collvol">4</param>
<param name="collvolpages">401</param>
<param name="year">1963</param>
<param name="prep">cv4p0401</param>
</template></extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="4514062/4">This compound is widely used in organic chemistry because it reacts with<space/><link><target>aldehyde</target><trail>s</trail></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>ketone</target><trail>s</trail></link><space/>to give 1,3-<link><target>dithiolane</target><trail>s</trail></link>, which are useful intermediates.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="doi">
<param name="1">10.1002/047084289</param>
</template>R. E. Conrow "Ethanedithiol" in Encyclopedia of Reagents for Organic Synthesis (Ed: L. Paquette) 2004, J. Wiley &amp; Sons, New York.<space/><template name="doi">
<param name="1">10.1002/047084289</param>
</template></extension></paragraph><list type="ident"><listitem><list type="ident"><listitem><sentence id="4514062/5">C<xhtml:sub xmlns:xhtml="">2</xhtml:sub>H<xhtml:sub xmlns:xhtml="">4</xhtml:sub>(SH)<xhtml:sub xmlns:xhtml="">2</xhtml:sub><space/>+ RR'CO ??C<xhtml:sub xmlns:xhtml="">2</xhtml:sub>H<xhtml:sub xmlns:xhtml="">4</xhtml:sub>S<xhtml:sub xmlns:xhtml="">2</xhtml:sub>CRR' + H<xhtml:sub xmlns:xhtml="">2</xhtml:sub>O</sentence></listitem></list></listitem></list><paragraph><link><target>Image:Carbonyl-protection-with-ethanedithiol-2D.png</target><part>center</part><part>400px</part><part>Protecting a carbonyl group by converting it to a 1,3-dithiolane, using 1,2-ethanedithiol</part></link></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="4514062/6">Other 1,2- and 1,3-dithiols undergo this reaction to give related 1,3-dithiolanes and 1,3-dithianes (six-membered rings).</sentence><space/><sentence id="4514062/7"><link><target>Diol</target><trail>s</trail></link><space/>such as<space/><link><target>ethylene glycol</target></link><space/>undergo analogous reactions to 1,3-<link><target>dioxalane</target><trail>s</trail></link><space/>and 1,3-<link><target>dioxane</target><trail>s</trail></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="4514062/8">One distinguishing feature of the dithiolanes and dithianes derived from aldehydes is that the methyne group can be deprotonated and the resulting carbanion alkylated.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><extension extension_name="references"/></paragraph><paragraph><template name="DEFAULTSORT:Ethanethiol, 1,2-">\n</template><sentence id="4514062/9"><link><target>Category:Thiols</target></link><link><target>Category:Reagents for organic chemistry</target></link><link><target>Category:Chelating agents</target></link></sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="4514062/10"><link><target>it:1,2-etanditiolo</target></link><link><target>ja:1,2-????????????</target></link><link><target>zh:??????</target></link></sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="4520461/0"><bold>1/8</bold><space/>may refer to:</sentence></paragraph><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence id="4520461/1"><link><target>1st Battalion 8th Marines</target></link></sentence></listitem><listitem>the<space/><sentence id="4520461/2"><link><target>calendar date</target></link><space/><link><target>January 8</target></link><space/>(USA)</sentence></listitem><listitem>the calendar date<space/><sentence id="4520461/3"><link><target>1 August</target></link><space/>(UK)</sentence></listitem><listitem>the<space/><sentence id="4520461/4"><link><target>fraction (mathematics)</target><part>fraction</part></link><space/>one eighth or 0.125 in<space/><link><target>decimal</target></link></sentence></listitem></list><paragraph><template name="numberdis">\n</template></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="246894/0">The<space/><bold>10-in-1 food parcel</bold>, commonly known as the<space/><bold>10-in-1 ration</bold><space/>was a field ration prepared for soldiers of the<space/><link><target>United States Army</target></link>, intended to provide one meal for 10 men.</sentence><space/></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="246894/1">Although the possibility of packing the<space/><link><target>B ration</target></link><space/>in units of ten was suggested early in the<space/><link><target>Second World War</target></link>, progress on such an arrangement did not begin until 1943 when the <link synthetic="true"><target>Mountain ration</target><part>Mountain</part></link>, Jungle, and 5-in-1 rations were discontinued.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/2">The success of the British "<link><target>compo</target></link>" or 14-in-1 ration during the North African campaign in 1942 and the movement to classify field rations into four categories added incentive for development of the 10-in-1 ration.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="multiref1">Koehler, Franz A.,<space/><italics>Special Rations for the Armed Forces: Army Operational Rations - A Historical Background</italics>, QMC Historical Studies, Historical Branch, Office of the Quartermaster General, Washington, D.C. (1958)</extension><space/><sentence id="246894/3">A guide to its rapid development was furnished in the following 1943 definition:<extension extension_name="blockquote">"A small-group field ration [shall be] composed of components of the standard field ration type B (modified to reduce bulk and weight) packed in basic packages of five complete rations each. . . . The inner and outer packages are to be proof against water, vapor, moisture, and chemical agents. They are to be of such shape and dimensions as to be suitable for either animal-pack or man-carry, and sufficiently sturdy as to material and construction to withstand normal handling and transportation in motor vehicles, on pack animals or by individual portage."<extension extension_name="ref" name="multiref1"/></extension></sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="246894/4">Specification requirements were quickly published, and the ration was standardized as the replacement for other group rations such as the<space/><link><target>5-in-1 ration</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/5">Although superseding the 5-in-1, the 10-in-l was essentially two 5-in-1s packed in one unit.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/6">Within such a combination, a greater variety of contents was possible; the number of "menus" was increased to five, compared to the three-menu arrangement of the 5-in-1.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/7">In ensuing war years, several revisions were made to the original specification, but their intended purpose of providing one day's food for ten men, remained unaltered.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/8">Within the daily plan, complete group meals were specified for breakfast and supper while a "partial dinner unit was provided for the luncheon meal.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="multiref1"/><space/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="246894/9">A typical menu included such canned items as butter-substitute spread, soluble coffee, pudding, meat units, jam, evaporated milk, and vegetables as well as biscuits, cereal, beverages, candy, salt, and sugar.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/10">Accessory items were cigarettes, matches, can opener, toilet paper, soap, towels, and water-purification (Halazone) tablets.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/11">The partial dinner unit was enclosed in a cellophane bag-in-carton for easy distribution to the individual soldier for his noontime meal.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/12">Within the unit were biscuits, a confection, beverage powder, sugar, gum, and a can opener.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/13">These items were provided on the theory that an individual "snack" was sufficient for midday meals, when there would be neither time nor opportunity to prepare the ration for group feeding.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="multiref1"/><space/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="246894/14">The similarity of the partial unit to the<space/><link><target>K ration</target></link><space/>was a chief reason for the proposed revision of the 10-in-1 in 1945.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/15">The revised 10-in-1 was intended for use during and after the<space/><link><target>Operation Downfall</target><part>1945 planned attack on Japan</part></link><space/>during<space/><link><target>World War II</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/16">It was planned to eliminate the unit ration concept, and to assemble the entire ration on the basis of three group meals rather than two group meals and one individual luncheon package.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/17">Although it was recognized that the overall weight of the ration would be increased thereby, it was felt that the added weight would be offset by the increased acceptability and nutritional value which a greater variety of components would provide.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/18">The end of the war prevented realization of such a plan in the 10-in-1, leaving a surplus of food.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/19">Through the form of<space/><link><target>CARE Package</target><trail>s</trail></link>, the humanitarian group<space/><link><target>Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere</target><part>CARE</part></link><space/>provided a means to transfer the ration surplus to those starving in<space/><link><target>Europe</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph><preblock><preline/></preblock><paragraph><sentence id="246894/20">Over 300 million rations, costing about 85 cents each, were procured under the 10-in-1 title from mid-1943 to the end of the <link synthetic="true"><target>World War II</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/21">No other group ration was procured during that period.</sentence> <sentence id="246894/22">Hence, in actuality as well as nomenclature, "<link synthetic="true"><target>B ration</target><part>Ration</part></link>, 10-in-1" was the final small-group ration of <link synthetic="true"><target>World War II</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="multiref1"/></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="246894/23">One 10-in-1 contained:</sentence></paragraph><list type="bullet"><listitem>one pound of<space/><sentence id="246894/24"><link><target>beef</target></link><space/>in<space/><link><target>broth</target></link><space/></sentence></listitem><listitem>one pound of<space/><sentence id="246894/25"><link><target>steak</target></link><space/>and kidneys<space/></sentence></listitem><listitem>8 ounces of<space/><sentence id="246894/26"><link><target>liver loaf</target></link><space/></sentence></listitem><listitem>8 ounces of<space/><sentence id="246894/27"><link><target>corned beef</target></link><space/></sentence></listitem><listitem>12 ounces of<space/><sentence id="246894/28"><link><target>luncheon loaf</target></link><space/>(similar to<space/><link><target>Spam (food)</target><part>Spam precooked meat product</part></link>)</sentence></listitem><listitem>8 ounces of<space/><sentence id="246894/29"><link><target>bacon</target></link></sentence></listitem><listitem>2 pounds of<space/><sentence id="246894/30"><link><target>margarine</target></link><space/></sentence></listitem><listitem>one pound of<space/><sentence id="246894/31"><link><target>lard</target></link><space/></sentence></listitem><listitem>one pound of<space/><sentence id="246894/32"><link><target>fruit preserves</target></link><space/></sentence></listitem><listitem>one pound of<space/><sentence id="246894/33"><link><target>honey</target></link></sentence></listitem><listitem>one pound of<space/><sentence id="246894/34"><link><target>raisin</target><trail>s</trail></link><space/></sentence></listitem><listitem>one pound of<space/><sentence <section><preblock><preline><space/></preline></preblock><paragraph><sentence id="22163759/0">In<space/><link><target>Zoroastrianism</target></link>,<space/><bold>101 names of <link synthetic="true"><target>names of God</target><part>God</part></link></bold><space/>(<link><target>Pazand</target></link><space/><italics>Sad-o-yak nam-i-khoda</italics>) is a list of<space/><link><target>names of God</target></link><space/>(<link><target>Ahura Mazda</target></link>).The list is preserved in<space/><link><target>Persian language</target><part>Persian</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Pazand</target></link>?and<space/><link><target>Gujarati language</target><part>Gujarati</part></link>.</sentence><space/><sentence id="22163759/1"><link><target>Parsi</target></link><space/>tradition expanded this to a list of "1001 names of <link synthetic="true"><target>names of God</target><part>God</part></link>".</sentence><extension extension_name="ref">Antonio Panaino,<space/><italics>The lists of names of Ahura Mazd? (Ya?t I) and Vayu (Ya?t XV)</italics>, 2002, p. 20.</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="22163759/2">The 101 names are often taken during Baj (ceremonial prayer) during the<space/><link><target>Yasna</target></link><space/>ritual while sprinkling the ring made of eight metals with the hair of the pure Varasya (a cow with only white hair), into the water vessel.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="PersianDNA">http://persiandna.com/101names.htm</extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="22163759/206"><bold>101 <link synthetic="true"><target>101 Names of God</target><part>Names of God</part></link></bold><space/>is a prayer created by<space/><link><target>Meher Baba</target></link><space/>through translation of a<space/><link><target>Zoroastrianism</target><part>Zoroastrian</part></link><space/>enumeration of "101 <link synthetic="true"><target>names of God</target><part>Names of</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Ahura Mazda</target></link>" into English.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><italics>Meher Prabhu: Lord Meher, The Biography of the Avatar of the Age, Meher Baba</italics>, Bhau Kalchuri, Manifestation, Inc. 1986. p. 6124</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="22163759/207">Of the prayer <link synthetic="true"><target>Meher Baba</target></link> said, "If you repeat this prayer with Love, no other prayer remains to be said.</sentence> <sentence id="22163759/208">Anyone can repeat these names with Love, irrespective of the religion he belongs to.</sentence>"<extension extension_name="ref"><italics>Meher Prabhu: Lord Meher, The Biography of the Avatar of the Age, Meher Baba</italics>, Bhau Kalchuri, Manifestation, Inc. 1986. p. 6121</extension><space/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="22163759/209">A book on <link synthetic="true"><target>Meher Baba</target><part>Meher Baba's</part></link> the 101 <link synthetic="true"><target>101 Names of God</target><part>Names of God</part></link> was written by<space/><link><target>Gujarati language</target><part>Gujarati</part></link><space/>scholar Sohrabji M.</sentence> <sentence id="22163759/210">Desai,<extension extension_name="ref"><italics>Meher Prabhu: Lord Meher, The Biography of the Avatar of the Age, Meher Baba</italics>, Bhau Kalchuri, Manifestation, Inc. 1986. p. 3227</extension><space/>editor of the <link synthetic="true"><target>Gujarati language</target><part>Gujarati</part></link> Biography of<space/><link><target>Upasni Maharaj</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><italics>Ibid</italics>, pp. 403-404</extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="948039/4"><link><target>Radio Victory</target></link><space/>launched as the first local radio service in the <link synthetic="true"><target>South Hampshire</target><part>South</part></link> of <link synthetic="true"><target>England</target></link> in 1975, transmitting to a small area around Portsmouth.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/5">The licence was re-advertised by the<space/><link><target>Independent Broadcasting Authority</target></link><space/>The extended license, now to include <link synthetic="true"><target>Southampton Airport</target><part>Southampton</part></link> and Winchester, was won by <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target><part>Ocean</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Sound</part></link> Ltd.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/6"><link synthetic="true"><target>Radio Victory</target></link> ceased operations in June 1986, a couple of weeks earlier than the expiry date of its franchise, with a test transmission informing listeners of the closure.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="948039/7"><link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target><part>Ocean</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Sound</part></link> launched on 12 October 1986 from a new purpose-built broadcast unit, built in just a year, in a business park in<space/><link><target>Segensworth</target></link><space/>West, outside<space/><link><target>Fareham</target></link>, <link synthetic="true"><target>South Hampshire</target><part>Hampshire</part></link> and near the<space/><link><target>M27 motorway</target></link>, a strategic location to prevent bias towards the two major cities of <link synthetic="true"><target>Southampton Airport</target><part>Southampton</part></link> and Portsmouth, as well as removing association with<space/><link><target>Radio Victory</target></link>, who were Portsmouth biased, however, some staff were hired from<space/><link><target>Radio Victory</target></link>, such as sales managers and a Head of News.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="948039/8">Two services were launched, <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target><part>Ocean</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Sound</part></link> (West), using 103.2<space/><link><target>MHz</target></link><space/>FM and 1557<space/><link><target>kHz</target></link><space/>AM covering <link synthetic="true"><target>Southampton Airport</target><part>Southampton</part></link> and Winchester, and <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target><part>Ocean</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Sound</part></link> (East) using 97.5<space/><link><target>MHz</target></link><space/>FM, moving from<space/><link><target>Radio Victory</target><part>Radio Victory's</part></link><space/>95.0&nbsp;<link synthetic="true"><target>Hertz</target><part>MHz</part></link> FM, and 1170<space/><link><target>kHz</target></link><space/>AM serving Portsmouth and the surrounding area.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/9">Two stations launched, rather than one station, as then Managing Director David Lucas identified two potential audiences, the East area familiar with commercial radio (in the East area) and the West area familiar with <link synthetic="true"><target>BBC Radio Solent</target><part>BBC</part></link>, specifically the popular <link synthetic="true"><target>BBC Radio Solent</target><part>BBC</part></link> station,<space/><link><target>BBC Radio Solent</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/10">The East area sounded livelier and there was a more softer sound for the West.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/11">The two stations were later joined by a separate service provided for Winchester and the surrounding areas on 96.7&nbsp;<link synthetic="true"><target>Hertz</target><part>MHz</part></link> FM, entitled <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target><part>Ocean</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Sound</part></link> (North) - The Light FM, launched on 6 December 1987,</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="948039/12">The two original stations shared daytime output with specialist programmes for each station, such as a Saturday evening Isle of Wight programme with Jean-Paul Hansford on the West station on 103.2, while Guy Hornsby's Saturday Soul Club on East, with the North service having its own programmes initially for 6am-2pm and then 5-9pm also, but relayed West at other times.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/13">The new station were well received and relevant, as suggested by slogan "We're on your wavelength.</sentence>"</paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="948039/14">In 1987, as part of<space/><link><target>Independent Broadcasting Authority</target><part>IBA</part></link>'s demand to end<space/><link><target>simulcasting</target></link><space/>on FM and AM, the services were reorganised.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/15">The FM West service became The <link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target></link> and East service became <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target><part>Ocean</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Sound</part></link>, with the respective AM services becoming The <link synthetic="true"><target>Gold (radio)</target><part>Gold</part></link> AM.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/16">The North service became The Light FM.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="948039/17"><link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target></link> launched on Sunday 4 December 1988 at 10&nbsp;am.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/18"><link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target></link> was designed as a direct competitor to<space/><link><target>BBC Radio 1</target></link><space/>in the area, with a heavy rotation of chart and<space/><link><target>Top 40</target></link><space/>pop and mainstream dance, with quick hourly news and information.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/19">The station was a music-intensive approach designed to get at the emerging demand for chart music which wasn't available locally, whereas sister station <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target><part>Ocean</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Sound</part></link> now provided significantly more speech, coupled with slightly older adult contemporary music.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/20">The opening presenter line-up included Pete Wardman, Bernie Simmons, <link synthetic="true"><target>Chris Pearson (radio)</target><part>Chris</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Dave Kelly (broadcaster)</target><part>Kelly</part></link>, Adrian Lovett,<space/><link><target>Chris Pearson (radio)</target><part>Chris Pearson</part></link><space/>and Judy James.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/21">The launch of <link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target></link> was one hour after that of <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target><part>Ocean</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Sound</part></link> and The <link synthetic="true"><target>Gold (radio)</target><part>Gold</part></link> AM so that the presenters on <link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target><part>Power</part></link> could say that they were Britain's newest radio station.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="948039/22">In 1992, the station and its sister stations were subsequently merged with<space/><link><target>Sussex</target></link><space/>radio station<space/><link><target>Southern FM</target><part>Southern Sound</part></link><space/>to form<space/><link><target>Southern Radio plc</target></link>, which was due to its location in a prosperous and commercially attractive area of<space/><link><target>England</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/23">The merger saw <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target><part>Ocean</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Sound</part></link> and The Light FM merging to create <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target><part>Ocean</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Sound</part></link> - Classic <link synthetic="true"><target>The Hit Music Network</target><part>Hits</part></link>, later <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target></link>, and The <link synthetic="true"><target>Gold (radio)</target><part>Gold</part></link> AM and <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern FM</target><part>Southern Sound's</part></link> AM frequencies merging to create<space/><link><target>South Coast Radio</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="948039/24"><link><target>File:PowerFM NewLogo.PNG</target><part>frame</part><part>GCap Era Logo</part><trail>In</trail></link><space/>1994,<space/><link><target>Capital Radio Group</target></link>, looking for expansion possibilities, purchased <link synthetic="true"><target>Southern Radio plc</target></link>, which led to on-air sound changes.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/25">Whilst sister-station <link synthetic="true"><target>Ocean FM</target></link> would take on a softer sound, <link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target></link> took on<space/><link><target>Capital Radio</target><part>Capital FM</part></link>'s long-established, successful and highly-polished sound, with news bulletins at the top of the hour finishing with the sentence "And that's the way it is at <time check>".</sentence> <sentence id="948039/26">In 2005,<space/><link><target>GWR Group</target><part>GWR</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Capital Radio Group</target></link><space/>merged to form<space/><link><target>GCap Media</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/27">In 2008,<space/><link><target>GCap Media</target></link><space/>was bought by<space/><link><target>Global Radio</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="948039/33">The station was rebranded as 103.2 <link synthetic="true"><target>103.2 Capital FM</target><part>Capital FM</part></link> on 3 January 2011 as part of a merger of <link synthetic="true"><target>Global Radio</target><part>Global Radio's</part></link><space/><link><target>The Galaxy Network</target><part>Galaxy</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>The Hit Music Network</target><part>Hit Music</part></link><space/>networks to form the nine-station<space/><link><target>The Capital FM Network</target><part>Capital FM Netork</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://www.brandrepublic.com/news/1028137/Global-Radio-takes-Capital-national/?DCMP=ILC-SEARCH">Global Radio takes Capital national</link>, Brand Republic, 13 September 2010</extension><space/><sentence id="948039/34">Current breakfast presenters Zoe Hanson and Paul Gillies retained their jobs with the relaunched station while Adam Inker moved from his weekday afternoon timeslot to host drivetime.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/35">The new station also saw the introduction of a new presenter for Weekend Breakfast - Christian Williams, the former Weekend overnight <link synthetic="true"><target>The Hit Music Network</target><part>Hit Music Network</part></link> presenter based at Trent FM in Nottingham.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://radiotoday.co.uk/news.php?extend.6470.2">Local Capital line-ups revealed</link>, RadioToday, 16 November 2010</extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="948039/114"><link><target>File:Flying Eye.jpg</target><part>thumbnail</part><part>right</part><part>250px</part><part>Power FM Flying Eye (<link><target>Piper Cherokee</target></link>)</part><trail>The</trail></link><space/>localised flagship programme airs weekdays from 06:00 until 10:00 on 103.2 <link synthetic="true"><target>103.2 Capital FM</target><part>Capital FM</part></link>, currently known as<space/><italics><link synthetic="true"><target>Capital Radio Group</target><part>Capital</part></link> Breakfast with Zoe and Gillies</italics>, currently presented by Zoe Hanson and Paul Gillies.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="capitalbreakfast"/><space/><sentence id="948039/115">Both of which joined the station, as <link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target></link>, in September 2007, having previously had worked at<space/><link><target>95.8 Capital FM</target></link>.</sentence><space/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="948039/116">Until November 2010, They were joined by <link synthetic="true"><target>Mark Ovenden</target><part>Mark</part></link> 'Sparky' Colerangle a second co-presenter and travel reader.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/117"><link synthetic="true"><target>Traffic Radio</target><part>Traffic</part></link> reports are broadcast every fifteen minutes from the Travel Centre between 6.30am until 9am, with drivers calling in to alert listeners of any problems, as well as Roadcrew reports from the Thunders.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/118">Travel previously took place from the Flying Eye, sponsored by<space/><link><target>O2 plc</target><part>O2</part></link>, which flew at 2500&nbsp;feet above the <link synthetic="true"><target>South Hampshire</target><part>South</part></link> of <link synthetic="true"><target>England</target></link> in a light aircraft based at<space/><link><target>Southampton Airport</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/119">For many years in the mid 1990s, the Flying Eye reporter was<space/><link><target>Spencer Kelly</target></link><space/>(real name <link synthetic="true"><target>Spencer Kelly</target><part>Spencer</part></link> Bignell), known as Commander <link synthetic="true"><target>Dave Kelly (broadcaster)</target><part>Kelly</part></link>, who went on to present<space/><link><target>Ocean FM</target></link><space/>breakfast and now presents<space/><link><target>Click (TV series)</target><part>Click</part></link><space/>on the <link synthetic="true"><target>BBC Radio Solent</target><part>BBC</part></link> News <link synthetic="true"><target>Channel 4 Radio</target><part>Channel</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="948039/120">The show was previously presented by Rick Jackson, the longest serving member of the show, joining in 1996, Rachel Brookes later replaced by Donna Alos, and Bob Diggles, known on air as Maximum Bob, until July 2007.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/121">Another regular member of the team was Handy Andy the Producer, an "expert" guitar player, who organised an unofficial song for<space/><link><target>England national football team</target><part>England</part></link><space/>during<space/><link><target>2004 European Football Championship</target><part>Euro 2004</part></link>, sold in shops across<space/><link><target>Hampshire</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="948039/122"><link><target>File:Travis at Power Amped 3.jpg</target><part>right</part><part>thumb</part><part>200px</part><part>Travis performing at Power Amped 3.</part><trail>Power</trail></link><space/>Amped was a concert held occasionally by the radio station at <link synthetic="true"><target>Southampton Airport</target><part>Southampton</part></link> Guildhall.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/123">It featured rock style bands and was designed to appeal to more mature music tastes than previous event <link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target><part>Power</part></link> in the Park.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/124">Between each of the acts, Maximum Bob DJ'd for the crowd, with other <link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target></link> presenters coming on stage to talk to the crowd and to introduce the next act.</sentence> <sentence id="948039/125">There have been a total of three:</sentence></paragraph><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence id="948039/126"><link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target><part>Power</part></link> Amped 1 =<space/><link><target>El Presidente (band)</target><part>El Presidente</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Kubb</target></link>,<space/><link><target>The Delays</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Embrace (English band)</target><part>Embrace</part></link></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="948039/127"><link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target><part>Power</part></link> Amped 2 = GunAngel (a school band that won a competition to open the concert),<space/><link><target>Captain (band)</target><part>Captain</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Vega4</target></link>,<space/><link><target>The Zutons</target></link></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="948039/128"><link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target><part>Power</part></link> Amped 3 =<space/><link><target>The Hoosiers</target></link>,<space/><link><target>The Twang</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Travis (band)</target><part>Travis</part></link></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="948039/129"><link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target><part>Power</part></link> in the Park ran for 10 years and was held at southampton common</sentence></listitem></list><paragraph><sentence id="948039/130">In 2008, <link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target></link> had another live event, <link synthetic="true"><target>Power FM</target><part>Power</part></link> Jam.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="948039/131">As <link synthetic="true"><target>Galaxy Radio</target><part>Galaxy</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Heart South Coast (regional)</target><part>South Coast</part></link>:</sentence></paragraph><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence id="948039/132">Love <link synthetic="true"><target>The Hit Music Network</target><part>Music</part></link>: Live!</sentence> =<space/><sentence id="948039/133"><link><target>Alesha Dixon</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Tinchy Stryder</target></link>,<space/><link><target>JLS</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Booty luv</target><part>Booty Luv</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Taio Cruz</target></link><space/>(who pulled out due to voice issues)</sentence></listitem></list><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence id="948039/134">Other events the station - As <link synthetic="true"><target>Galaxy Radio</target><part>Galaxy</part></link>, and presumably now as <link synthetic="true"><target>103.2 Capital FM</target><part>Capital FM</part></link> too - have promoted and run competitions for tickets include<space/><link><target>95.8 Capital FM London</target></link>'s Summertime Ball and Jingle Bell Ball in 2009 and 2010, held at<space/><link><target>The O2 Arena (London)</target></link><space/>in early June and December, respectively.</sentence></listitem></list></section>

<param name="end">January 3, 1995</param>
<param name="vp"><link><target>Dan Quayle</target></link><space/>(R), until Jan. 20, 1993<xhtml:br xmlns:xhtml=""/><link><target>Al Gore</target></link><space/>(D),after Jan. 20, 1993</param>

<param name="sessionend2">December 1, 1994</param>
<param name="previous">102nd</param>
<param name="next">104th</param>
</template><sentence id="456541/0">The<space/><bold>One Hundred Third <link synthetic="true"><target>103rd United States Congress</target><part>United States Congress</part></link></bold><space/>was a meeting of the legislative branch of the <link synthetic="true"><target>United States Senate</target><part>United States</part></link> federal government, composed of the<space/><link><target>United States Senate</target></link><space/>and the<space/><link><target>United States House of Representatives</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="456541/1">It met in<space/><link><target>Washington, DC</target></link><space/>from January 3, 1993 to January 3, 1995, during the first two years of<space/><link><target>Bill Clinton</target></link>'s<space/><link><target>President of the United States</target><part>presidency</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="456541/2">The apportionment of seats in the<space/><link><target>United States House of Representatives</target><part>House of Representatives</part></link><space/>was based on the<space/><link><target>1990 United States Census</target><part>Twenty-first Census of the United States in 1990</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="456541/3">Both chambers had a<space/><link><target>Democratic Party (United States)</target><part>Democratic</part></link><space/>majority.</sentence><template name="TOClimit">
<param name="1">2</param>
</template></paragraph></section>

Street</part></link> was closed, and eventually demolished.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="5573567/12">The station has gone by a number of different names.</sentence> <sentence <section><paragraph><template name="for">
<param name="1">other units with the same regimental number</param>
<param name="2">105th Regiment of Foot (disambiguation)</param>
</template><sentence id="25864740/0">The<space/><bold>105th <link synthetic="true"><target>105th Regiment of Foot (Queen's Own Royal Regiment of Highlanders)</target><part>Regiment of Foot (Queen's Own Royal Regiment of Highlanders)</part></link></bold><space/>was a short-lived British<space/><link><target>line infantry</target></link><space/>regiment.</sentence> <sentence id="25864740/1">It was raised in<space/><link><target>Perthshire</target></link><space/>by Maj-Gen<space/><link><target>David Graeme</target></link><space/>as a two-battalion regiment on 15th October 1760, by converting independent companies<extension extension_name="ref">Adam and Innes, The<space/><italics>Clans, Septs and Regiments of the Scottish Highlands</italics><space/>(1934)</extension><space/>- its name was in honour of<space/><link><target>Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz</target></link>, who had already been selected as the wife for the future<space/><link><target>George III of England</target></link><space/>(the marriage occurred in 1761).</sentence> <sentence id="25864740/2">It served in Ireland and was disbanded in 1763.</sentence></paragraph></section>

</template></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="21691544/0"><bold><italics>106 &amp; <link synthetic="true"><target>106 & Gospel</target><part>Gospel</part></link></italics></bold><space/>was an inspirational version of the top-ten video countdown show<space/><italics><link><target>106 &amp; Park</target></link></italics>, that aired Sundays on<space/><link><target>Black Entertainment Television</target><part>BET</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="21691544/1">The show debuted on January 11, 2009 and features a live audience, gospel music videos, choir battles and many celebrity guest.</sentence> <sentence id="21691544/2">The show was canceled in April 2009 due to low ratings on the network.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="21691544/3">The program played the top ten most requested videos of the day, as requested by viewers who can vote by telephone or online.</sentence> <sentence id="21691544/4">In addition to the music video countdown, a typical show also aired one new music video known as the New Joint of the Day, and a music video from the past known as the Flashback Joint of the Day.</sentence> <sentence id="21691544/5">Viewers were also able to view videos from singers who talk about how<space/><link><target>Good news (Christianity)</target><part>the gospel</part></link><space/>had a impact in their lives.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://www.bet.com/onblast/default.html?chan=3&amp;id=2718&amp;i=8&amp;sub=3&amp;itype=v">KIERRA'S CORNER</link></extension><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://www.bet.com/onblast/default.html?chan=3&amp;id=2622&amp;i=3&amp;sub=2&amp;itype=v">Salt in a different Season</link></extension><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://www.bet.com/onblast/default.html?chan=3&amp;id=2563&amp;i=1&amp;sub=&amp;itype=e">One-on-one:Kierra On the Rise</link></extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="21691544/6">Angel Taylor from<space/><link><target>Trin-i-tee 5:7</target></link><space/>and Jor'el Quinn from 21:03 were the hosts of the show.</sentence> <sentence id="21691544/7">The show also featured <link synthetic="true"><target>Tye Tribbett</target></link>, where his segment "<link synthetic="true"><target>Tye Tribbett</target><part>Tye's</part></link> Tidbits",<link synthetic="true"><target>Tye Tribbett</target><part>Tye</part></link> talked about upcoming events and releases from gospel singers.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://www.bet.com/onblast/default.html?chan=3&amp;id=2670&amp;i=6&amp;sub=&amp;itype=e">One-On-One: Jor'el &amp; Angel</link></extension></paragraph></section>

</template><sentence id="20495501/0">The<space/><bold>106th <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link></bold><space/>(later reorganized as a <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment</part></link>) was a mechanized cavalry unit of the<space/><link><target>United States Army</target></link><space/>in World <link synthetic="true"><target>Spanish American War</target><part>War</part></link> II.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/1">The 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link> had previously been known as the<space/><link><target>1st Regiment Illinois Volunteer Cavalry</target></link><space/>during the<space/><link><target>Spanish American War</target></link><space/>and World <link synthetic="true"><target>Spanish American War</target><part>War</part></link> I and was constituted in 1921 as part of the Illinois <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>National Guard</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/2">It underwent a number of reorganizations before World <link synthetic="true"><target>Spanish American War</target><part>War</part></link> II.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/3">Like other guard units during the inter-war years, the 106th held monthly drills and yearly training.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/4">Readiness for war in 1940 led to the mechanization of the unit and induction into Federal Service at<space/><link><target>Camp Livingston</target></link>, Louisiana on 25 November 1940.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/5">After the<space/><link><target>Attack on Pearl Harbor</target><part>Pearl Harbor</part></link><space/>attack, the 106th trained at<space/><link><target>Fort Hood</target><part>Camp Hood</part></link>, Texas until the spring of 1944 when they deployed to <link synthetic="true"><target>Western Allied invasion of Germany</target><part>Europe</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/6">Upon arriving in England, the group was reorganized into the 106th and 121st Cavalry <link synthetic="true"><target>Reconnaissance</target></link> Squadrons along with a <link synthetic="true"><target>Twelfth United States Army Group</target><part>Group</part></link> Headquarters.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/7">After arriving in <link synthetic="true"><target>Western Allied invasion of Germany</target><part>Europe</part></link>, they were often in the lead of other units.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/8">Lightly armed, they scouted ahead to fix enemy locations.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/9">For the next year and a half, they fought through France, Luxembourg, Germany and Austria, earning five campaign streamers and the<space/><link><target>Croix de guerre</target></link><space/>from<space/><link><target>Charles de Gaulle</target></link>, President of the Provisional <link synthetic="true"><target>First Army (France)</target><part>French</part></link> government.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/10">The <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment</part></link> lead the Allied advance across the<space/><link><target>Rhine</target></link>, and were the first unit to attack a town south of the<space/><link><target>Siegfried Line</target></link><space/>or <link synthetic="true"><target>Siegfried Line</target><part>West Wall</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/11">In late 2006, the<space/><link><target>33rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team (United States)</target><part>33rd Brigade Combat Team</part></link><space/>of the<space/><link><target>Illinois Army National Guard</target></link><space/>was formed and the 106th Cavalry Squadron was included in the reorganization.</sentence></paragraph></section>
<section></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/12"><bold>Blazon</bold></sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/13"><italics>Shield</italics><space/>Per fess dovetailed Or and Gules, in base four fleurs-de-lis, three and one, of the first.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="shield"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/14"><italics>Crest</italics><space/>That for the regiments and separate battalions of the <link synthetic="true"><target>Illinois Army National Guard</target></link>: On a wreath of the colors Or and Gules upon a grassy field the blockhouse of old <link synthetic="true"><target>Fort Hood</target><part>Fort</part></link> Dearborn, Proper.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="shield"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/15"><italics>Motto</italics><space/>UTCUMQUE UBIQUE (Anywhere At Any Time).</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="shield"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/16"><bold>Symbolism</bold></sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/17"><italics>Shield</italics><space/>The shield is divided per fess dovetailed Or and Gules (yellow and red), denoting that the organization has served as Artillery as well as Cavalry.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/18">Red and yellow, being the <link synthetic="true"><target>Spanish American War</target><part>Spanish</part></link> colors, also indicate <link synthetic="true"><target>Spanish-American War</target></link> service within the continental limits of the <link synthetic="true"><target>United States Army</target><part>United States</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/19">The fleurs-de-lis on the red portion symbolize the combat operations of the organization in <link synthetic="true"><target>Western Allied invasion of Germany</target><part>Europe</part></link> during World <link synthetic="true"><target>Spanish American War</target><part>War</part></link> I and World <link synthetic="true"><target>Spanish American War</target><part>War</part></link> II.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="shield"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/20"><italics>Crest</italics><space/>The crest is that of the <link synthetic="true"><target>Illinois Army National Guard</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="shield"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/21"><bold>Background</bold></sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/22">The coat of arms was originally approved for the 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Regiment</part></link>, Illinois and Michigan <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>National Guard</part></link> on 17 December 1930.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/23">The description wording was modified on 30 December 1932 to show the unit's correct period of service on the Mexican Border.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/24">The unit was redesignated as the 106th Heavy <link synthetic="true"><target>Stuart tank</target><part>Tank</part></link> Battalion, Illinois and Michigan <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>National Guard</part></link> on 3 October 1949.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/25">The shield was amended to delete the crest for organizations of the Michigan <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>National Guard</part></link> on 6 October 1949.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/26">Four years later, on 19 October 1953 the unit was redesignated as the 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>Stuart tank</target><part>Tank</part></link> Battalion, Illinois <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>National Guard</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/27">The insignia was redesignated for the 106th Armor <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment</part></link>, Illinois <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>National Guard</part></link> on 13 December 1960.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/28">It was redesignated once again as the 106th <link 1965.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/29">It was amended to change the symbolism of the shield of the coat of arms on 7 October 1969.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="shield"/></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/34">The 106th Cavalry was before World <link synthetic="true"><target>Spanish American War</target><part>War</part></link> II a <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>National Guard</part></link> unit based in Chicago, Illinois.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/35">Prior to World <link synthetic="true"><target>Spanish American War</target><part>War</part></link> I and the<space/><link><target>Spanish-American War</target></link><space/>it had been known as the<space/><link><target>1st Regiment Illinois Volunteer Cavalry</target><part>1st Illinois Volunteer Cavalry</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/36">The 106th underwent a number of different reorganizations until 1 September 1940, when it was redesignated the 1st Squadron, 106th Cavalry (Horse-Mechanized).</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/37">The 106th was inducted into federal service on 25 November 1940 in Chicago.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/38">The <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment</part></link> moved to<space/><link><target>Camp Livingston</target></link>, Louisiana on 3 January 1941 under command of<space/><link><target>V Corps</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="geocities"/></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/42">Along with other <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>National Guard</part></link> units, the regiment was federalized in 1940.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/43">At the beginning of World <link synthetic="true"><target>Spanish American War</target><part>War</part></link> II, most of the members of the regiment were given the opportunity to enroll in officers school.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/44">A core group of about 60 men chose to stay with the unit.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/45">The <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment</part></link> was assigned to the<space/><link><target>United States Army Central</target><part>Third Army</part></link><space/>on 12 January 1942, and to<space/><link><target>IV Corps</target></link><space/>on 1 May 1942.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/46">In spring 1942 the <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment</part></link> became fully mechanized.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite web">

</template></extension><space/><sentence id="20495501/47">The regiment participated in several maneuvers at Hineston, Kinisatchie, and Dry Creek, Louisiana; and in the Louisiana Maneuver Area through Embarkation for England.</sentence></paragraph><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence id="20495501/50">Constituted: 1921.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="20495501/51">Activated: 25 <section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/69">The 106th fought continuously throughout the European campaign.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/70">After the<space/><link><target>Battle of the Bulge</target></link>, they were attached to the<space/><link><target>7th Army</target></link>,<space/><link><target>45th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>45th Infantry Division</part></link>, which had entered <link synthetic="true"><target>Western Allied invasion of Germany</target><part>Europe</part></link> through Italy and fought their way up into France.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/71">Although comprising approximately fifteen hundred men, the unit was often given assignments that stretched it thin, and they were recognized with the award of two<space/><link><target>Croix de guerre</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/72">The unit finished out the war with the 7th <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>Army, XV Corps</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/73">The 106th was the first American troops to enter<space/><link><target>Salzburg</target></link>, Austria.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/74">They received information from the 101st Squadron that the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>Germans</part></link> were holding the<space/><link><target>Leopold III of Belgium</target><part>King and Queen of Belgium</part></link><space/>prisoner in a chateau near<space/><link><target>Strobl</target></link>, Austria.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/75">Captain Benning, the commander of B Troop, led some of his unit, including individuals who spoke <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link>, on a rescue party.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/76">The group later served as <link synthetic="true"><target>Legion of Honor</target><part>Honor</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>Guards</part></link> for the <link synthetic="true"><target>Leopold III of Belgium</target><part>King and Queen of Belgium</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/77">The 106th secured a truce from the defending <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>Army</part></link> on 7 May, the day before the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> High Command surrendered to the Allies on 8 May 1945.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="geocities"/></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/78">The 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group's</part></link> purpose was to act as the eyes and ears of its parent unit, scouting ahead of slower, heavier-equipped<space/><link><target>armoured warfare</target><part>armored</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>infantry</target></link><space/>units to seek out the enemy.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/79">When enemy forces were found, they were to engage them, determine their size and position, and report this information to the command.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/80">If able, they would engage the enemy until resistance was too great, when heavier units would be called on to finish the job.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://www.louisdimarco.com/106thcavalry.htm</param>
<param name="title">106th Cavalry Group</param>
<param name="author">Louis DiMarco</param>
<param name="accessdate">27 November 2008</param>
</template><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://www.louisdimarco.com/106thcavalry.htm</param>
<param name="title">106th Cavalry Group</param>
<param name="author">Louis DiMarco</param>
<param name="accessdate">27 November 2008</param>
</template></extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/81">Along with its<space/><link><target>reconnaissance</target></link><space/>duties, the Cavalry was used to fill vulnerable gaps in the lines between Allied units and assigned special missions that required rapid movement around and even behind static enemy lines.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><link><target>Image:Bantam-jeep-1.jpg</target><part>thumb</part><part/><part>The Bantam Jeep came in many configurations. The 106th Bantam vehicles were equipped with .30 caliber machine guns or mortars.</part></link><link><target>Image:M8-Greyhound-Haugh-3.jpg</target><part>thumb</part><part>left</part><part>The M8 Greyhound was equipped with a 37mm gun, three machine guns, and two powerful radios.</part></link><link><target>Image:M5A1 firing.JPG</target><part>thumb</part><part>M5A1 Stuart Light Tank firing its 37mm gun.</part></link><sentence id="20495501/82">The 106th Cavalry was lightly equipped to allow it to move quickly and deploy rapidly.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/83">They fought mounted in mobile <link synthetic="true"><target>Willys MB</target><part>Bantam Jeeps</part></link> and M8 armored cars.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/84">Each Squadron's complement of troops and vehicles consisted of a Headquarters Troop that included communication, administrative, mess, maintenance, transportation, and supply support, a Medical Detachment, a Cavalry <link synthetic="true"><target>assault gun</target><part>Assault Gun</part></link> Troop, and three <link synthetic="true"><target>Reconnaissance</target></link> Troops, lettered A, B, and C.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/85">A squadron of about 760 men was about the equivalent of a typical <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>Army</part></link> unit's battalion in numbers, though Cavalry units were typically smaller.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="bayonet"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/86">The three <link synthetic="true"><target>Reconnaissance</target></link> Troops were each equipped with<space/><link><target>Willys MB</target><part>Bantam jeeps</part></link><space/>with a bracket-mounted<space/><link><target>M1919 Browning machine gun</target><part>.30 caliber machine gun</part></link>, manned by a soldier sitting in the front passenger seat.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/87">A second <link synthetic="true"><target>Willys MB</target><part>Bantam jeep</part></link> was mounted with a<space/><link><target>M2 Mortar</target><part>60mm mortar</part></link><space/>manned by two soldiers.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/88">Sometimes the <link synthetic="true"><target>Willys MB</target><part>Bantam</part></link> was mounted with a<space/><link><target>M2 Browning machine gun</target><part>.50 caliber machine gun</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="bayonet"/><space/><sentence id="20495501/89">Each Troop was usually equipped with a mixture of the three vehicles.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/90">To maximize speed and maneuverability on the battlefield, the <link synthetic="true"><target>Willys MB</target><part>Bantams</part></link> were not given extra armor protection.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="geocities"/><space/><sentence id="20495501/91">The only modifications the 106th made was to add a wire cutter.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/92">They mounted a steel pole on the front bumper that extended above the driver's head because the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>Germans</part></link> would sometimes stretch piano wire over roads with the intention of injuring or decapitating the driver.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="kappelman"/><template name="rp">
<param name="1">80</param>
</template></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/93">The third vehicle used was the six-wheeled, light-weight<space/><link><target>M8 Greyhound</target></link><space/>armored car, mounted with a<space/><link><target>37 mm Gun M3</target><part>37&nbsp;mm</part></link><space/>gun in a movable turret that could swing a full 360 degrees.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/94">It also featured a .30 caliber coaxial machine gun that could move independently of the turret.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/95">The M8 was equipped with powerful FM radios to enable battlefield communications.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/96">E Troop, the Squadron's mobile artillery, was the Cavalry <link synthetic="true"><target>assault gun</target><part>Assault Gun</part></link> Troop and consisted of three <link synthetic="true"><target>assault gun</target><part>Assault Gun</part></link> Platoons.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/97">Each platoon was equipped with<space/><link><target>assault gun</target><trail>s</trail></link>, short-barreled<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">75</param>
<param name="2">mm</param>
</template><space/>howitzers in an open turret on an M8 chassis.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/98">They also utilized two<space/><link><target>M2 Half Track Car</target><part>halftracks</part></link><space/>to carry their headquarters unit and an <link synthetic="true"><target>ammunition box</target><part>Ammunition</part></link> Section.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/99">Two <link synthetic="true"><target>assault gun</target><part>Gun</part></link> Sections used an <link synthetic="true"><target>M8 Greyhound</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="bayonet"><template name="cite web">

</template><template name="cite web">
