<param name="accessdate">2 December 2008</param>
<param name="archiveurl">http://web.archive.org/web/20080801081611/http://www.bayonetstrength.150m.com/Reconnaissance/united_states_cavalry_reconnaiss.htm</param>
<param name="archivedate">1 August 2008</param>
</template></extension></paragraph><paragraph><link><target>Image:M24 May 1945.jpg</target><part>thumb</part><part>The new M24 Chaffee light tank that was issued to the 106th Cavalry in February 1945. Its 75&nbsp;mm gun was vastly superior to the Stuart tank.</part></link><sentence id="20495501/100">F Troop consisted of five light tank companies.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/101">Early in the war, each company had three Light <link synthetic="true"><target>Stuart tank</target><part>Tank</part></link> Platoons, consisting of five<space/><link><target>37 mm Gun M3</target><part>37mm</part></link><space/><link><target>Stuart tank</target><part>M5A1 Stuart</part></link><space/>light tanks.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/102">While fast and maneuverable, the <link synthetic="true"><target>Stuart tank</target><part>Stuart's</part></link> armor plating and its cannon were soon found to be no match against the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> tanks.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/103">In February 1945, they were replaced with the more heavily armed<space/><link><target>75 mm gun (US)#M6</target><part>75&nbsp;mm</part></link><space/><link><target>M24 Chaffee</target></link><space/>light tank.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="bayonet"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/104">The M5 <link synthetic="true"><target>Stuart tank</target><part>Stuart</part></link> light tank was capable of speeds up to<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">36</param>
<param name="2">mi/h</param>
<param name="3">km/h</param>
<param name="abbr">on</param>
</template><space/>on the road, while the <link synthetic="true"><target>M24 Chaffee</target></link> could travel at speeds up to<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">37</param>
<param name="2">mi/h</param>
<param name="3">km/h</param>
<param name="abbr">on</param>
</template><space/>on paved surfaces.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/105">The M8 armored car was capable of speeds of up to<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">50</param>
<param name="2">mi/h</param>
<param name="3">km/h</param>
<param name="abbr">on</param>
</template>, while the <link synthetic="true"><target>Willys MB</target><part>Bantams</part></link> could exceed<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">70</param>
<param name="2">mi/h</param>
<param name="3">km/h</param>
</template>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/106">The officers usually rode with their enlisted men in the <link synthetic="true"><target>Willys MB</target><part>Bantams</part></link>, while the squadron's support troops used a variety of vehicles including the <link synthetic="true"><target>Willys MB</target><part>Bantams</part></link>, military trucks, and armored<space/><link><target>M2 Half Track Car</target><part>halftracks</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/107">At times, the men would dismount from their light vehicles and take on infantry roles, digging in to create a stronger defensive line.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/108">Patrols were undertaken both on foot or mounted as the circumstances dictated.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/109">In this capacity, the cavalrymen would go into combat with<space/><link><target>M1 Garand rifle</target><part>M1 rifles</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>carbines</target></link>, hand grenades,<space/><link><target>Thompson submachine gun</target><part>Thompson machine guns</part></link>, and newly developed<space/><link><target>bazooka</target><trail>s</trail></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/110">When facing heavily fortified enemy positions or, later in the war, against the heaviest <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> tanks, the 106th was accompanied with supporting units, usually in the form of a small number of<space/><link><target>tank destroyers</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/111">However, the mission of reconnaissance units was not to kill all of the enemies encountered, but to summon the slower moving and better equipped infantry and armored units whose job it was to fix and destroy the heavily armored enemy.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="geocities"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/112">The Headquarters, Maintenance, Mess, Supply and Medical units were equipped with a variety of military trucks, M8 <link synthetic="true"><target>armoured warfare</target><part>Armored</part></link> cars, halftracks, and <link synthetic="true"><target>Willys MB</target><part>Bantam jeeps</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/113">The regiment arrived at<space/><link><target>Glasgow</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Scotland</target></link><space/>on 9 March 1944, was moved to Doddington Hall camp in England, and six days later was reorganized.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/114">Rechristened as the HHT 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link> (Mechanized), it comprised the 106th and 121st Cavalry <link synthetic="true"><target>Reconnaissance</target></link> Squadrons along with a <link synthetic="true"><target>Twelfth United States Army Group</target><part>Group</part></link> Headquarters, with half of its officers and non-commissioned soldiers making up the newly formed 121st Cavalry Squadron.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/115">The 33rd Aviation Battalion of the Illinois <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>National Guard</part></link> was reorganized as Troop A.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="ilnatguard"/><space/><sentence id="20495501/116">After three months of training, the 106th sailed for France on 29 June 1944.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/117">While crossing the English Channel to <link synthetic="true"><target>Western Allied invasion of Germany</target><part>Europe</part></link>, the Squadron was transported on two<space/><link><target>Liberty ship</target><trail>s</trail></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/118">The <link synthetic="true"><target>Liberty ship</target></link> carrying A Troop of the 121st Squadron hit a mine shortly after leaving England.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/119">Fortunately, a Red <link synthetic="true"><target>Distinguished Service Cross (United States)</target><part>Cross</part></link><space/><link><target>Landing Ship, Tank</target><part>LST</part></link><space/>came quickly alongside and all the men were safely evacuated back to England for another 19 days before new transportation to France could be found.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/120">They fought continuously throughout the European campaign.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/121">After the<space/><link><target>Battle of the Bulge</target></link>, they were attached to the<space/><link><target>7th Army (United States)</target><part>7th Army</part></link>,<space/><link><target>45th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>45th Infantry Division</part></link>, which had entered <link synthetic="true"><target>Western Allied invasion of Germany</target><part>Europe</part></link> through Italy and fought their way up into France.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/122">They finished out the war with the 7th <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>Army</part></link>,<space/><link><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/123">The 106th were the first American troops to enter<space/><link><target>Salzburg</target></link>, Austria.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><link><target>Image:Coutances.jpg</target><part>left</part><part>thumb</part><part>M5A1 Stuart Light Tank passes through the wrecked streets of<space/><link><target>Coutances</target></link>.</part></link><sentence id="20495501/124">The 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link> arrived in France under the command of Colonel <link synthetic="true"><target>Vennard Wilson</target></link>, a Regular <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>Army</part></link> officer.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/125">They were first committed to combat on 2 July 1944 with the<space/><link><target>VIII Corps (United States)</target><part>VIII Corps</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/126">Its first mission was to mop up <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> forces that had been cut off during the drive of the <link synthetic="true"><target>VIII Corps (United States)</target><part>VIII Corps</part></link> down the <link synthetic="true"><target>Invasion of Normandy</target><part>Normandy</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Brittany</target><part>Peninsula</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/127">The next mission was an offensive screening mission, which led from <link synthetic="true"><target>Invasion of Normandy</target><part>Normandy</part></link> south through St.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/128">James, Isigny, La Haye-du-Puits, Manche, Basse-Normandie, <link synthetic="true"><target>Coutances</target><part>Coutance</part></link>, and Avaranches, to <link synthetic="true"><target>Rennes</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="williams"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://mars.wnec.edu/~dwilliam/history/106cav.html</param>
<param name="author">Donald C. Williams</param>
<param name="accessdate">29 November 2008</param>
<param name="title">106th Cavalry Group</param>
</template><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://mars.wnec.edu/~dwilliam/history/106cav.html</param>
<param name="author">Donald C. Williams</param>
<param name="accessdate">29 November 2008</param>
<param name="title">106th Cavalry Group</param>
</template></extension><space/><sentence id="20495501/129">With the quick advance, gaps appeared between <link synthetic="true"><target>VIII Corps (United States)</target><part>VIII</part></link> and <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link>, and <link synthetic="true"><target>Major General</target><part>General</part></link><space/><link><target>George S. Patton</target></link><space/>plugged the gap between<space/><link><target>Louvign?-de-Bais</target><part>Louvigne</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Rennes</target></link><space/>with the 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="ironponies"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://etd.lib.fsu.edu/theses/available/etd-03302004-164302/unrestricted/Chapter11.pdf</param>
<param name="format">PDF</param>
<param name="title">Men on "Iron Ponies", The Death and Rebirth of the Modern U. S. Cavalry.<space/><italics>Chapter 11: The Arrival of the Cavalry Groups, D-Day to the West Wall</italics></param>
<param name="author">Matthew Darlington Morton</param>
<param name="date">18 March 2004</param>
</template><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://etd.lib.fsu.edu/theses/available/etd-03302004-164302/unrestricted/Chapter11.pdf</param>
<param name="format">PDF</param>
<param name="title">Men on "Iron Ponies", The Death and Rebirth of the Modern U. S. Cavalry.<space/><italics>Chapter 11: The Arrival of the Cavalry Groups, D-Day to the West Wall</italics></param>
<param name="author">Matthew Darlington Morton</param>
<param name="date">18 March 2004</param>
</template></extension><template name="rp">
<param name="1">369</param>
</template></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/130">When <link synthetic="true"><target>VIII Corps (United States)</target><part>VIII Corps</part></link> turned west to mop up and secure the<space/><link><target>Brittany</target><part>Brittany Peninsula</part></link>, the 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment</part></link> was reassigned once again to<space/><link><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/131">As the <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link> raced east towards <link synthetic="true"><target>Le Mans, France</target><part>Le Mans,</part></link> the 106th provided reconnaissance and a screening force.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/132">Members of the 106th were among the first to enter<space/><link><target>Le Mans, France</target><part>Le Mans</part></link><space/>on 8 August.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/133">The <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> front in the<space/><link><target>operation Overlord</target><part>Battle of Normandy</part></link><space/>had collapsed, and the <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link> turned north to help close the<space/><link><target>Falaise Pocket</target></link><space/>and the 106th screened their flank.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/134">The <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link> then turned north towards the<space/><link><target>Seine</target></link><space/>and Paris.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/135">With the pocket closed, the 106th led the way east through Alen?on, Sarthe, Nogent, and Mantes-Gassicourt.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/136">On 15 August they covered the<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">50</param>
<param name="2">mi</param>
<param name="3">km</param>
<param name="adj">on</param>
</template><space/>to<space/><link><target>Dreux</target></link>, just west of Paris, in a single day.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="ironponies"/><template name="rp">
<param name="1">369</param>
</template><space/><sentence id="20495501/137">They remained there covering the <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link>' flank until 27 August.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/138">This mission helped protect <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link> against the enemy desperately trying to escape the<space/><link><target>Falaise Pocket</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="williams"/><space/><sentence id="20495501/139">The advance east from Auxerre to Gondrecourt was one of the fastest of the war.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/140">Their screening mission took them along a<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">90</param>
<param name="2">mi</param>
<param name="3">km</param>
<param name="adj">on</param>
</template><space/>front from the left to the right flank of the<space/><link><target>Third Army (United States)</target><part>Third Army</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="geocities"/><extension extension_name="ref" name="williams"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/141">The regiment was then transferred under the command of and assigned to protect the right flank of<space/><link><target>XII Corps (United States)</target><part>XII Corps</part></link><space/>for twelve days carrying out reconnaissance as that corps advanced east.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/142">In mid-September it was reassigned to <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link> at<space/><link><target>Joinville, Haute-Marne</target><part>Joinville</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/143">This marked a two-month and<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">400</param>
<param name="2">mi</param>
<param name="3">km</param>
<param name="adj">on</param>
</template><space/>trek across France as they moved in to protect the right flank of<space/><link><target>Third Army (United States)</target><part>U.S. Third Army</part></link><space/>during their rapid advance from <link synthetic="true"><target>Joinville, Haute-Marne</target><part>Joinville</part></link> au Marne to<space/><link><target>Meurthe-et-Moselle</target><part>Charmes au Moselle</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/144">During this advance, the 106th along with the<space/><link><target>2nd Armored Division (France)</target><part>2nd French Armored Division</part></link><space/>helped close in on the<space/><link><target>16th Infantry Division (Germany)</target><part>German 16th Infantry Division</part></link>, which was completely destroyed in the ensuing combat.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="geocities"/><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/145">The 106th's commanding officer, Colonel <link synthetic="true"><target>Vennard Wilson</target></link>, later described the unit's action:</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><template name="bquote">
<param name="We used five of our six troops to contain those Germans, slipped around to their north, delivered our infantry on their objective at five in the afternoon after a fifty-mile advance. I wish to pay special tribute to B Troop 106th Squadron and their gallant troop commander, Captain Park, in this operation. This troop was one hundred miles in rear of us when the advance was ordered, came up during the night, arrived at the starting point after the other troops had departed, kept moving as rear troop during the day, and were sent into action late in the afternoon after I had committed the five other troops. Captain Park used one of his platoons on side blocking and reconnaissance missions, and when I arrived at Charmes we had only Captain Park, two platoons, and a platoon of tanks. It was enough to do the job.<ref name">"williams"/></param>
</template></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/146">In late September, the <link synthetic="true"><target>Third Army (United States)</target><part>U.S.</part></link></sentence> <sentence id="20495501/147"><link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>Army</part></link> transferred the <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link> from <link synthetic="true"><target>Major General</target><part>General</part></link> Patton's<space/><link><target>Third Army (United States)</target><part>Third Army</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Twelfth United States Army Group</target><part>12th Army Group</part></link><space/>to<space/><link><target>Seventh Army (United States)</target><part>Seventh Army</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Sixth United States Army</target><part>6th Army Group</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/148">Reassigned with the <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link>, the 106th??ithout moving positions??witched from guarding the <link synthetic="true"><target>United States Army Central</target><part>Third Army's</part></link> right flank to guarding the <link synthetic="true"><target>Seventh Army (United States)</target><part>Seventh Army's</part></link> left flank and maintaining contact between the <link synthetic="true"><target>United States Army Central</target><part>Third</part></link> and <link synthetic="true"><target>Seventh Army (United States)</target><part>Seventh Armies</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="geocities"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/149">The 106th was then tasked with reconnaissance in front of the <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/150">They led the <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link> from the<space/><link><target>Moselle River</target></link><space/>to<space/><link><target>Lun?ville</target></link>, and supported by the 813th <link synthetic="true"><target>813th Tank Destroyer Battalion (united States)</target><part>Tank Destroyer Battalion</part></link><extension extension_name="ref" name="tankdestroyer"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://homepage.mac.com/yeide/TDBattalionHistories.htm</param>
<param name="accessdate">1 December 2008</param>

</template><template name="cite web">

<param name="title">Tank Destroyer Battalion Histories</param>
</template></extension>, attacked northeast into the wooded For?t de Parroy, northeast of<space/><link><target>Lun?ville</target></link>, France.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/151">For two months they fought as infantrymen, dismounted alongside the<space/><link><target>79th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>79th</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>44th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>44th Infantry Division</part><trail>s</trail></link>, overcoming winter weather and thick minefields.</sentence><space/><sentence id="20495501/152"><link><target>Major General</target></link><space/><link><target>Wade H. Haislip</target></link><space/>characterized For?t de Parroy as being "in reality a jungle.</sentence>"<extension extension_name="ref" name="ironponies"/><template name="rp">
<param name="1">392</param>
</template></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/153">During what was said to be the worst winter in 30 years, the 1500 men of the 106th held up to<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">125</param>
<param name="2">mi</param>
<param name="3">km</param>
<param name="adj">on</param>
</template><space/>of the front.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/154">Staying in contact with the <link synthetic="true"><target>XII Corps (United States)</target><part>XII Corps</part></link> right flank to its north was difficult because its lines were so thinly spread.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/155">Maintaining relatively static lines from 20 September through 5 November, they took the opportunity to rotate the two squadrons in and out of the line as<space/><link><target>trench foot</target></link><space/>took its toll on the soldiers.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/156">On several occasions the 106th was called on to push back <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> attacks and with the help of a tank destroyer group, repulsed <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> attacks.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/157">The 121st Cavalry Squadron was later awarded the<space/><link><target>Croix de guerre</target></link><space/>with <link synthetic="true"><target>Mentioned in Despatches</target><part>Palm</part></link> for its gallantry under fire during this extended period.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="geocities"/><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/158">When the <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link>' infantry destroyed the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German's</part></link> defenses, the 106th, once again supported by the<space/><link><target>813th Tank Destroyer Battalion (united States)</target><part>813th Tank Destroyer Battalion</part></link><extension extension_name="ref" name="tankdestroyer"/>, preceded the<space/><link><target>2nd Armored Division (France)</target><part>2nd French Armored Division</part></link><space/>in their advance through the<space/><link><target>Vosges Mountains</target></link><space/>to within<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">1</param>
<param name="2">mi</param>
<param name="3">km</param>
<param name="adj">on</param>
</template><space/>of the<space/><link><target>Rhine River</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/159">The 106th was once again out front, leading the attack on<space/><link><target>Sarrebourg</target></link><space/>and then advancing<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">16</param>
<param name="2">mi</param>
<param name="3">km</param>
<param name="adj">on</param>
</template><space/>to the east to seize the<space/><link><target>Col de Saverne</target><part>Saverne Gap</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/160">Once through the <link synthetic="true"><target>Col de Saverne</target><part>Gap</part></link>, the 106th guarded the northwest flank near <link synthetic="true"><target>Sarrebourg</target></link> as the rest of the <link synthetic="true"><target>V Corps</target><part>Corps</part></link> advanced east another<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">33</param>
<param name="2">mi</param>
</template><space/>to capture<space/><link><target>Strasbourg</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/161">On the American's<space/><link><target>Thanksgiving (United States)</target><part>Thanksgiving Day</part></link>, 23 November 1944, one of the most ?lite units in the entire <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> army, the well-rested and refitted<space/><link><target>Panzer-Lehr-Division</target></link><space/>counterattacked, trying to recapture the <link synthetic="true"><target>Col de Saverne</target><part>Saverne Gap</part></link> and cut off the <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corp</part></link> from its supply lines.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/162">The 106th was credited with completing a brilliant delaying action, giving <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link> Commander <link synthetic="true"><target>Major General</target></link><space/><link><target>Wade H. Haislip</target></link><space/>time to reinforce their positions and push the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>Germans</part></link> back.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/163">Two weeks later, on 16 December 1944, the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>Germans</part></link> launched the<space/><link><target>Ardennes Offensive</target></link><space/>(<link synthetic="true"><target>Battle of the Bulge</target></link>).</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/164">The 106th was deployed as infantry, patrolling north of <link synthetic="true"><target>Sarrebourg</target></link> to confirm the location of the enemy.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/165">On 23 December the <link synthetic="true"><target>Twelfth United States Army Group</target><part>Group</part></link> relieved the<space/><link><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>6th Cavalry Group</part></link><space/>of <link synthetic="true"><target>United States Army Central</target><part>Third Army</part></link> in its zone to the north.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/166">The 106th Squadron relieved the 28th Squadron near<space/><link><target>St. Avold</target></link><space/>and the 121st Squadron relieved the 6th Squadron near<space/><link><target>Freyming-Merlebach</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/167">The 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link> maintained position on the shoulder of the bulge, helping maintain contact with <link synthetic="true"><target>United States Army Central</target><part>Third Army</part></link> and check the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> attack.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/168">As the <link synthetic="true"><target>Ardennes Offensive</target></link> faltered, the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>Germans</part></link> launched<space/><link><target>Operation Nordwind</target></link><space/>just before midnight on New Year's Eve to try to relieve pressure on its troops in the <link synthetic="true"><target>Battle of the Bulge</target><part>Ardennes</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/169">They once again sought to recapture the <link synthetic="true"><target>Col de Saverne</target><part>Saverne Gap</part></link> and join up with the<space/><link><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German 19th Army</part></link>, enveloping seven American divisions along the <link synthetic="true"><target>Rhine River</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/170">The <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>Germans</part></link> attacked the right center of the <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment</part></link> and the group temporarily withdrew.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/171">The bitterly cold winter weather made fighting more difficult, but the 106th finally forced the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>Germans</part></link> to retreat.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/172">When the <link synthetic="true"><target>Ardennes Offensive</target></link> was stopped, the <link synthetic="true"><target>Seventh Army (United States)</target><part>Seventh Army</part></link> and the<space/><link><target>First Army (France)</target><part>French First Army</part></link><space/>resumed the offensive on 29 January 1945.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/173">The 106th continued to patrol until 11 February 1945, when it was relieved by the 101st <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/174">The regiment moved outside of <link synthetic="true"><target>Freyming-Merlebach</target><part>Merlebach</part></link> for rest, refitting, and equipment maintenance.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/175">They were outfitted with the new<space/><link><target>M-24</target></link><space/>'<link synthetic="true"><target>M24 Chaffee</target><part>Chaffee</part></link>' light tank with its improved 75&nbsp;mm gun mount, a huge improvement over the <link synthetic="true"><target>Stuart tank</target><part>M5A1's</part></link> 37&nbsp;mm gun.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/><space/><sentence id="20495501/176">Upon receiving the tanks in mid-February 1945, soldiers said, "The light tank companies of both squadrons turned in their 37mm gun-toting <link synthetic="true"><target>Stuart tank</target><part>M5A1's</part></link> and drew the new <link synthetic="true"><target>M24 Chaffee</target><part>M24's</part></link> Armed with a 75&nbsp;mm cannon and twice the size of the precursors, these tanks seemed beautiful to us.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/177">Our tankers itched to try them out.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/178">On 15 March, they got their chance.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/179">We were back in the line.</sentence>"<extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite book">

<section><paragraph><link><target>Image:Americans cross Siegfried Line.jpg</target><part>thumb</part><part>left</part><part>American soldiers cross the West Wall or Siegfried Line.</part></link><sentence id="20495501/180">After just over a month's break, the 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link> returned to the front lines.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/181">From 15 March to 26 March it led <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link>' offensive through the<space/><link><target>Siegfried Line</target></link><space/>near<space/><link><target>Saarbr?cken</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/182">Leading the advance across the <link synthetic="true"><target>Rhine</target></link> were A and B Troops of the 121st Squadron, the first to attack a town south of the<space/><link><target>Siegfried Line</target><part>West Wall</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite web">
<param name="title">Address to Members of 106 Cavalry Group Memorial Day, 30&nbsp;May 1945</param>

<param name="accessdate">29 November 2008</param>
</template><template name="cite web">

<param name="accessdate">29 November 2008</param>
</template></extension><space/><sentence id="20495501/183">Finally reaching the <link synthetic="true"><target>Rhine River</target></link>, on 27 March 1945 the 106th crossed the river and cleared and secured Salzbach.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/184">The <link synthetic="true"><target>Twelfth United States Army Group</target><part>Group</part></link> then covered the advance of <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link> to<space/><link><target>Aschaffenburg</target><part>Aschaffenburg am Main</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/185">The 106th secured the <link synthetic="true"><target>V Corps</target><part>Corps</part></link>' left flank and maintained contact with the<space/><link><target>44th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>44th</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>45th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>45th Infantry Division</part><trail>s</trail></link><space/>and the<space/><link><target>2nd Cavalry Division (United States)</target><part>2nd Cavalry Division</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/186">From 1 to 5 April, the regiment assisted the 2nd <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link>, advancing north to<space/><link><target>Bad Orb</target></link>, Germany and secured an Allied<space/><link><target>Prisoner of War camp</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/187">The <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment's</part></link> 121st Squadron was then charged with reconnoitering the main road to Neustadt.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/188">In the next eight days, the group moved northeast into Germany, rapidly cleared the towns of Alsberg, Siedensroth,<space/><link><target>Steinau an der Stra?e</target><part>Steinau</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Schl?chtern</target></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Flieden</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/189">From 5 April to 13 April, the regiment cleared the enemy eastward to the <link synthetic="true"><target>Aschaffenburg</target><part>Main</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Moselle River</target><part>River</part></link>, a tributary of the <link synthetic="true"><target>Rhine River</target></link>, covering the advance of the<space/><link><target>45th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>45th Infantry Division</part></link><space/>into<space/><link><target>Lauda-K?nigshofen</target></link><space/>and then on 20 April the capture of<space/><link><target>Nuremberg</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/190">On 21 April A Troop of the 106th Squadron was charged with leading the 2nd Battalion, 179th <link synthetic="true"><target>infantry</target><part>Infantry</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment</part></link>,<space/><link><target>5th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>5th Infantry Division</part></link><space/>about<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">160</param>
<param name="2">mi</param>
<param name="3">km</param>
<param name="adj">on</param>
</template><space/>south to the<space/><link><target>Danube River</target></link>, and to secure and hold a crossing near<space/><link><target>Neuburg an der Donau</target><part>Neuberg</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/191">During the next two days, the 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link> fought its final major engagement.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/192">From <link synthetic="true"><target>Neuburg an der Donau</target><part>Neuberg</part></link>, the unit attacked southward towards<space/><link><target>Augsburg</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/193">Leading the 45th <link synthetic="true"><target>45th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>Infantry Division</part></link> rapidly east<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">60</param>
<param name="2">km</param>
</template><space/>down the<space/><link><target>autobahn</target></link><space/>towards<space/><link><target>Munich</target></link><space/>as it tried to locate the rapidly retreating <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>Germans</part></link>, Troop C along with two light tanks from Company F, drew a concentrated attack from <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> forces only<space/><template name="convert">
<param name="1">5.6</param>
<param name="2">mi</param>
<param name="3">km</param>
<param name="adj">on</param>
</template><space/>from their objective.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/194">The <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> self-propelled guns, tanks, and small arms fire left four dead and destroyed four armored M8 vehicles and four <link synthetic="true"><target>Willys MB</target><part>Bantams</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/195">On 29 April, during the assault towards <link synthetic="true"><target>Munich</target></link>, the 3rd Battalion, 157th <link synthetic="true"><target>infantry</target><part>Infantry</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Regiment</part></link>, 45th <link synthetic="true"><target>45th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>Division</part></link> liberated the<space/><link><target>Dachau Concentration Camp</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/196">The 45th <link synthetic="true"><target>45th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>Infantry Division</part></link> for which the 106th had reconnoitered for several months, battled diehard Nazi troops and took <link synthetic="true"><target>Munich</target></link> on 30 April 1945.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="ironponies12"><template name="cite web">

<param name="1">441</param>
</template><space/><sentence id="20495501/197">After helping to capture <link synthetic="true"><target>Munich</target></link>, the 106th lead the <link synthetic="true"><target>XV Corps (United States)</target><part>XV Corps</part></link> into Austria.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/198">On 2 May, they received orders to capture <link synthetic="true"><target>Salzburg</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/199">Enroute, they captured the remnants of the<space/><link><target>Hungarian Third Army</target><part>Hungarian 9th Infantry Brigade</part></link>, about 8,800 men, who were retreating eastward, fighting the advancing Soviet Marshall<space/><link><target>Rodion Malinovsky</target></link>'s<space/><link><target>2nd Ukrainian Front</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/200"><link synthetic="true"><target>Salzburg</target></link> surrendered on 4 May, and the local <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> commander offered a truce.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/><extension extension_name="ref" name="ironponies12"/><template name="rp">

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/201">The group's final victory was the rescue of the<space/><link><target>Leopold III of Belgium</target><part>King of Belgium</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/202">Held in internal exile by the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>Germans</part></link> since his small nation had withstood a <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> attack for three weeks in May 1940, <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link>-speaking members of a small recon party of the 106th learned while searching the towns of<space/><link><target>St. Wolfgang im Salzkammergut</target><part>St. Wolfgang</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Strobl</target></link><space/>that<space/><link><target>Leopold III of Belgium</target><part>King Leopold</part></link><space/>was under guard in a villa in <link synthetic="true"><target>Strobl</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/203">Travelling in a six-wheeled Mercedes previously owned by Germany's Foreign Minister<space/><link><target>Joachim von Ribbentrop</target><part>Von Ribbentrop</part></link>,<extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://www.roberthjackson.org/Man/theman2-6-1</param>
<param name="title">Nuremberg: Memorial to Robert H. Jackson</param>

</template><template name="Dead link">
<param name="date">October 2010</param>
<param name="bot">H3llBot</param>
</template><template name="cite web">

</template><space/><template name="Dead link">
<param name="date">October 2010</param>
<param name="bot">H3llBot</param>
</template><space/>Von Ribbontrop's Mercedes was later used by<space/><link><target>Robert H. Jackson</target></link>, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and Chief Prosecutor of the<space/><link><target>Nuremberg Trials</target></link>.</extension><space/>the troops located the villa.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/204">The S.S.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/205"><link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>Guards</part></link> were still present, and the men of the 106th disarmed them without any resistance, freeing <link synthetic="true"><target>Leopold III of Belgium</target><part>King Leopold</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="dimarco"/></paragraph></section>

Merit</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Legion of Honor</target></link>, and<space/><link><target>Croix de guerre</target></link><space/>for his outstanding leadership of this unit.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/207">Lieutenant Benjamin S.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/208">Hill of the 121st Squadron was posthumously awarded the <link synthetic="true"><target>Distinguished Service Cross (United States)</target><part>Distinguished Service Cross</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="williams"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/209">The 121st Cavalry Squadron was awarded the<space/><link><target>Fourrag?re</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/210">For its action at <link synthetic="true"><target>Lun?ville</target></link>, the 121st Cavalry Squadron was recognized with the<space/><link><target>Croix de guerre</target></link><space/>with <link synthetic="true"><target>Mentioned in Despatches</target><part>Palm</part></link>, and the <link synthetic="true"><target>Croix de guerre</target><part>Croix de guerre with Palm</part></link> was awarded to entire 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Regiment</part></link> for their gallantry and action at Caen-<link synthetic="true"><target>Falaise Pocket</target><part>Falaise</part></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="williams"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/211"><link synthetic="true"><target>Major General</target><part>General</part></link><space/><link><target>Charles de Gaulle</target></link>'s citation praised the 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group's</part></link> action fighting alongside the 2nd <link synthetic="true"><target>First Army (France)</target><part>French</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>45th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>Division</part></link> into the <link synthetic="true"><target>Vosges Mountains</target></link>:</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><template name="bquote">
<param name="A magnificent Regiment, whose brilliant achievements, during the time in which it fought with and in support of the 2nd French Armored Division, from 20 August 1944 to 10 February 1945, command the highest admiration.  This Regiment conducted aggressive and extended reconnaissance form east of the MOULDRE towards CRESPIERRES as far as the MOSELLE at CHARMES, where it established and held a bridgehead without reinforcements; then near LUNEVILLE and BACCARAT engaged in protective and advanced guard missions, first at ANDELOT, then from the MARNE to the MOSELLE. In the MORTAGNE sector, the Regiment seized the town of MONT, overran VOUCOURT, and reached the line EMMERSVILLER-GEISLAUTERN-WADGASSEN, where it held stubbornly in the face of the strong German counter-attacks of 31 December 1944 and of 1 January 1945.  In the conduct of these operations the 106th Cavalry Group, U.S.A., showed a tenacity and vigor worthy of the greatest praise. Never allowing itself to be cut off even when it was engaged with a determined enemy force superior in numbers to its own, successfully accomplishing all the missions assigned to it, persistently seeking contact when the enemy concealed himself, this Regiment has proven itself possessed of the highest military attributes and of a combat proficiency without equal.<ref>{{cite web|url">http://family.phelpsinc.com/branches/beasley/myron_ricketts.asp|title=FRENCH CAMPAIGN EDICT NO 872 |accessdate=8 November 2008}}<space/><template name="Dead link">
<param name="date">October 2010</param>
<param name="bot">H3llBot</param>
</template></ref></param>
</template></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/212">T/5 Glenn Kappelman was among replacements who joined the unit on 1 February 1944, and he was able to take about 750 pictures of the unit's action during the remainder of the war.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/213">Against orders, Kapplelman had secreted a<space/><link><target>Kodak</target></link><space/><link><target>616 film</target><part>616</part></link><space/>camera in his gas mask during embarkation inspection in New York.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/214">Because he was a common soldier and not a professional photographer, and since cameras and film were rare among troops in combat, the photographs depict a soldier's everyday experience and are relatively unique among<space/><link><target>war photography</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="kappelman"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/215">Traveling in an M8 armored car, he stashed film in empty<space/><link><target>ammunition box</target><trail>es</trail></link>, shooting nearly 100 rolls of film.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/216">On one occasion during the winter of 1945 near <link synthetic="true"><target>Lun?ville</target></link>, his M8 was damaged and his squadron was forced to hastily retreat.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/217">Unable to carry his boxes of film, he hid them in a nearby home under a table covered by a long tablecloth.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/218">He returned two days later to find the ammunition boxes undisturbed.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="kappelman"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/219">Fifty years later, he began to produce large format prints of selected images and donated copies to the<space/><link><target>Fort Riley#Fort_Riley_Museums</target><part>United States Cavalry Museum</part></link><space/>at Ft.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/220">Riley, Kansas, and other collections.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/221">He also gave a set to the<space/><link><target>Baudouin I of Belgium</target><part>King of Belgium</part></link><space/>who had been 15 years old when he was rescued by Kappelman's unit from <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>German</part></link> captivity in 1945.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/222">Kappelman and fellow 106th veteran Art Barkis narrated a largely self-financed video documentary titled<space/><italics>Through My Sights: A Gunner's View of WWII</italics><space/>of the photographic collection in 1999.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/223">In 2003 he followed that with a book of the same name featuring a large number of the photos interspersed with his personal recollections 50 years later, along with excerpts from his wartime letters and diaries.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="kappelman"><template name="cite book">
<param name="author">Glenn L. Kappelman</param>
<param name="title">Through My Sights: A Gunner's View of WWII</param>
<param name="publisher">Sunflower Publishing</param>
<param name="year">2003</param>
<param name="isbn">0-9704764-1-8</param>
</template><template name="cite book">
<param name="author">Glenn L. Kappelman</param>
<param name="title">Through My Sights: A Gunner's View of WWII</param>
<param name="publisher">Sunflower Publishing</param>
<param name="year">2003</param>
<param name="isbn">0-9704764-1-8</param>
</template></extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/224">The 106th remained in Austria as an occupation force until October 1945.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/225">Part of their responsibility were acting as an <link synthetic="true"><target>Legion of Honor</target><part>Honor</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>Guard</part></link> for <link synthetic="true"><target>Leopold III of Belgium</target><part>King Leopold</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/226">The <link synthetic="true"><target>Leopold III of Belgium</target><part>King</part></link> was at the time a controversial figure because of his stand during the war and refusal to flee and set up a government in exile, but surrendered to the <link synthetic="true"><target>19th Army (Germany)</target><part>Germans</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/227">The 106th were billeted in Pension Appesbach next door to the <link synthetic="true"><target>Leopold III of Belgium</target><part>King's</part></link> chateau.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/228">They assisted with<space/><link><target>Military Police</target></link><space/>duties but otherwise relaxed, playing sports, swimming, boating, and sightseeing.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="kappelman"/><template name="rp">
<param name="1">112</param>
</template><space/><sentence id="20495501/229">Ironically, one member of B Troop, T/5 Myron Ricketts, having survived the war, died in a drowning accident during occupation duties.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://family.phelpsinc.com/branches/beasley/myron_ricketts.asp</param>
<param name="title">Tribute to T/5 Myron K. Ricketts, B Troop, 121st Squadron, 106th Cavalry Group</param>
<param name="accessdate">25 February 2009</param>
</template><template name="Dead link">
<param name="date">October 2010</param>
<param name="bot">H3llBot</param>
</template><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://family.phelpsinc.com/branches/beasley/myron_ricketts.asp</param>
<param name="title">Tribute to T/5 Myron K. Ricketts, B Troop, 121st Squadron, 106th Cavalry Group</param>
<param name="accessdate">25 February 2009</param>
</template><space/><template name="Dead link">
<param name="date">October 2010</param>
<param name="bot">H3llBot</param>
</template></extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/230">In a speech to the <link synthetic="true"><target>6th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Group</part></link> on Memorial <link synthetic="true"><target>Thanksgiving (United States)</target><part>Day</part></link>, 30 May 1945, commanding officer Colonel <link synthetic="true"><target>Vennard Wilson</target></link> described the <link synthetic="true"><target>Twelfth United States Army Group</target><part>Group's</part></link> and specifically Troop B's accomplishments:</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><template name="bquote">
<param name="Our regiment, approximately fifteen hundred men, rather small as a major combat unit, has carried its full share of the action from Normandy to Austria. We landed in Normandy on 2 July 1944, learned combat in the famous hedgerow fighting there, learned to make swift advances in the initial breakthrough to Avranches. Then came our first open runs, from Avranches to the Seine. We were ready, and took up the gallop for fifty- and sixty-mile runs, leading the pack all the way. When the Third Army paused for supplies, we covered its right flank for a length of one hundred and fifteen miles.  The advance began again and we were told to lead the XV Corps from the vicinity of Neufchateau to Charmes. That, from a tactical standpoint, was one of the most interesting and successful of our accomplishments. An entire German division??he 16th Infantry Division??as in front of us. Our communications and technique were then developed to such a high standard that our infantry following us hardly lost an hour.  We used five of our six troops to contain those Germans, slipped around to their north, delivered our infantry on their objective at five in the afternoon after a fifty-mile advance. I wish to pay special tribute to B Troop 106th Squadron and their gallant troop commander, Captain Park, in this operation. This troop was one hundred miles in rear of us when the advance was ordered, came up during the night, arrived at the starting point after the other troops had departed, kept moving as rear troop during the day, and were sent into action late in the afternoon after I had committed the five other troops. Captain Park used one of his platoons on side blocking and reconnaissance missions, and when I arrived at Charmes we had only Captain Park, two platoons, and a platoon of tanks. It was enough to do the job.<ref name">"williams"/></param>
</template></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/231">The 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>104th Cavalry Regiment (United States)</target><part>Cavalry Regiment</part></link> departed Austria for the <link synthetic="true"><target>United States Army</target><part>United States</part></link> on 1 October 1945 via New York and was inactivated in Urbana, Illinois on 24 October 1945.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="geocities"><template name="cite web">
<param name="accessdate">27 November 2008</param>
<param name="title">World War II History</param>
<param name="url">http://www.geocities.com/the_106th_cavalry/106th_WWII_History2.html</param>
<param name="archiveurl">http://www.webcitation.org/5keWNcz9Q</param>
<param name="archivedate">19 October 2009</param>
<param name="deadurl">yes</param>
</template><template name="cite web">
<param name="accessdate">27 November 2008</param>
<param name="title">World War II History</param>
<param name="url">http://www.geocities.com/the_106th_cavalry/106th_WWII_History2.html</param>
<param name="archiveurl">http://www.webcitation.org/5keWNcz9Q</param>
<param name="archivedate">19 October 2009</param>
<param name="deadurl">yes</param>
</template></extension><extension extension_name="ref" name="ilnatguard"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://www.il.ngb.army.mil/Museum/HistoricalEvents/WorldWarII.htm</param>
<param name="title">Illinois Army National Guard Units</param>
<param name="accessdate">30 November 2008</param>
<param name="archiveurl">http://web.archive.org/web/20080628044808/http://www.il.ngb.army.mil/Museum/HistoricalEvents/WorldWarII.htm</param>
<param name="archivedate">28 June 2008</param>
</template><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://www.il.ngb.army.mil/Museum/HistoricalEvents/WorldWarII.htm</param>
<param name="title">Illinois Army National Guard Units</param>
<param name="accessdate">30 November 2008</param>
<param name="archiveurl">http://web.archive.org/web/20080628044808/http://www.il.ngb.army.mil/Museum/HistoricalEvents/WorldWarII.htm</param>
<param name="archivedate">28 June 2008</param>
</template></extension><space/><sentence id="20495501/232">In 1952 Companies A and C of the 106th <link synthetic="true"><target>Stuart tank</target><part>Tank</part></link> Battalion were headquartered at <link synthetic="true"><target>Camp Livingston</target><part>Camp</part></link> Lincoln in Illinois.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="ilnatguard"/></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><template name="Main">
<param name="1">33rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team (United States)</param>
</template></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/233">In late 2006, the<space/><link><target>33rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team (United States)</target><part>33rd Brigade Combat Team</part></link><space/>of the<space/><link><target>Illinois Army National Guard</target></link><space/>was formed.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/234">A, B, and C Troops of 106th Cavalry Squadron along with its Headquarters Troop were included in the reorganization, forming the 33rd's<space/><link><target>RSTA</target><part>Reconnaissance, Survellience, and Target Acquisition</part></link><space/>squadron.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/235">Like their predecessors, they are responsible for reconnaissance, engaging the enemy with scout vehicles and anti-armor weapons, identifying and reporting enemy locations and activity, and providing enemy targeting information.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="ilnatguard"/><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://www.ngb.army.mil/news/archives/2006/09/090606-ILARNG_transform.aspx</param>
<param name="title">Illinois Army Guard Transformation Enhances Capabilities</param>
<param name="author">Stacey Rieger</param>
<param name="publisher">National Guard press release</param>
<param name="date">6 September 2006</param>
</template><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://www.ngb.army.mil/news/archives/2006/09/090606-ILARNG_transform.aspx</param>
<param name="title">Illinois Army Guard Transformation Enhances Capabilities</param>
<param name="author">Stacey Rieger</param>
<param name="publisher">National Guard press release</param>
<param name="date">6 September 2006</param>
</template></extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/236">On 2 and 16 August 2008, about 100 Soldiers of the Headquarters and Headquarters Troop and Troop C, 2nd Squadron, 106th Cavalry were honored in a deployment ceremony as they prepared to deploy to Afghanistan.</sentence> <sentence id="20495501/237">As part of the<space/><link><target>33rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team (United States)</target><part>33rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team</part></link>, they will act as <link synthetic="true"><target>Military Police</target><part>Police</part></link> Mentor Teams and will train and mentor<space/><link><target>Afghan National Police</target></link>, conducting patrol and security missions.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://www.il.ngb.army.mil/departments/pa/Pressreleases/pressreleases.asp</param>
<param name="title">Deployment Ceremony 16&nbsp;Aug for Aurora-based Unit</param>
<param name="date">11 August 2008</param>
<param name="accessdate">3 December 2009</param>
</template><template name="cite web">
<param name="url">http://www.il.ngb.army.mil/departments/pa/Pressreleases/pressreleases.asp</param>
<param name="title">Deployment Ceremony 16&nbsp;Aug for Aurora-based Unit</param>
<param name="date">11 August 2008</param>
<param name="accessdate">3 December 2009</param>
</template></extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="20495501/238">The remainder of the 106th Cavalry has since been assigned to <link synthetic="true"><target>Afghan National Police</target><part>Afghan National</part></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>Army National Guard</target><part>Army</part></link> mentoring missions as well as various other security operations as part of Combined Joint Task Force Phoenix <link synthetic="true"><target>VIII Corps (United States)</target><part>VIII</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence id="20495501/239"><link><target>Vennard Wilson</target></link>, commanding officer, later Brigadier <link synthetic="true"><target>Major General</target><part>General</part></link> and Assistant <link synthetic="true"><target>45th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>Division</part></link> Commander, 25th <link synthetic="true"><target>45th Infantry Division (United States)</target><part>Infantry Division</part></link></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="20495501/240"><link><target>James H. Polk</target></link>, squadron commander, later regimental executive officer, and Commander in Chief,<space/><link><target>Seventh United States Army</target><part>United States Army Europe</part></link><space/>from 1967 to 1971.</sentence></listitem></list></section>

<section><paragraph><extension extension_name="onlyinclude"><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence id="42463/1"><link><target>May 8</target></link><space/>&ndash;<space/><link><target>Alfonso VI of Castile</target></link><space/>marries<space/><link><target>Constance of Burgundy</target></link>.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="42463/2"><link><target>October 18</target></link><space/>&ndash; <link synthetic="true"><target>Alexius I Comnenus</target><part>Alexius I</part></link> helps defend<space/><link><target>Albania</target></link><space/>from the <link synthetic="true"><target>Normans</target></link> (the first recorded mention of <link synthetic="true"><target>Albania</target></link>), but is defeated at the<space/><link><target>Battle of Dyrrhachium (1081)</target><part>Battle of Dyrrhachium</part></link><space/>(<link><target>Durazzo</target></link>).</sentence> <sentence id="42463/3">The <link synthetic="true"><target>Normans</target></link> govern <link synthetic="true"><target>Albania</target></link> from <link synthetic="true"><target>Italy</target></link> until around 1100.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="42463/4"><link><target>Corfu</target></link><space/>is taken from the<space/><link><target>Byzantine Empire</target></link><space/>by<space/><link><target>Robert Guiscard</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Normans</target><part>Norman</part></link><space/><link synthetic="true"><target>King of Poland</target><part>King of</part></link> Southern<space/><link><target>Italy</target></link>.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="42463/5"><link><target>Byzantine emperor</target></link><space/><link><target>Nicephorus III</target></link><space/>is overthrown by<space/><link><target>Alexius I Comnenus</target></link>, ending the Middle<space/><link><target>Byzantine Empire</target><part>Byzantine</part></link><space/>period and beginning the<space/><link><target>Comnenus</target><part>Comnenan dynasty</part></link>.</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="42463/6"><link><target>Turkish people</target><part>Turkish</part></link><space/>emir<space/><link><target>Chaka Bey</target></link><space/>conquers<space/><link><target>?zmir</target></link><space/>and founds a short lived principality and emerges as the first sea power in <link synthetic="true"><target>Turkish people</target><part>Turkish</part></link> history.</sentence><space/></listitem><listitem><sentence id="42463/7">Construction begins on<space/><link><target>Saint Canute's Cathedral</target></link><space/>in<space/><link><target>Odense</target></link>.</sentence></listitem></list></extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><template name="orphan">
<param name="date">December 2008</param>
</template><template name="for">
<param name="1">other units with the same regimental number</param>
<param name="2">109th Regiment of Foot (disambiguation)</param>
</template><sentence id="12502522/0">The<space/><bold>109th (<link synthetic="true"><target>109th (Aberdeenshire) Regiment of Foot</target><part>Aberdeenshire) Regiment of Foot</part></link></bold><space/>was an<space/><link><target>infantry</target></link><space/>regiment of the<space/><link><target>British Army</target></link><space/>from 1794 to 1795.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="12502522/1">Colonel Alexander Hay of Rannes, a former officer of the<space/><link><target>104th Regiment of Foot</target></link>, persuaded the King<space/><link><target>William IV of the United Kingdom</target><part>William IV</part></link><space/>to grant him permission to raise his own regiment in<space/><link><target>Aberdeenshire</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Scotland</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="12502522/2">He used an ingenious method of recruiting men by paying each volunteer a bounty of Five Pounds then further authorising a raffle amongst every twenty recruits whereby the winner would receive 100 pounds and permission to buy his discharge for twenty pounds, thus providing the winner with an eighty pound profit plus the original 5 pound bounty.</sentence> <sentence id="12502522/3">By 4 September 1794 the 109th Regiment comprised twenty-three officers plus seven hundred and eighteen enlisted NCOs and men.</sentence> <sentence id="12502522/4">Posterity does not record how many men took advantage of the twenty pound discharge fee.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="12502522/5">The Regiment, having formed marched to<space/><link><target>Dundee</target></link><space/>at the end of September thence via<space/><link><target>Burntisland</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Fife</target></link><space/>to<space/><link><target>Southampton</target></link>,<space/><link><target>England</target></link><space/>in late October.</sentence> <sentence id="12502522/6">Upon arriving in <link synthetic="true"><target>Southampton</target></link> the 109th embarked for the<space/><link><target>Bailiwick of Jersey</target></link><space/>for eight months and in 1795 joined General<space/><link><target>James Abercrombie</target><part>Abercrombie</part></link><template name="dn">
</template>'s force bound for the<space/><link><target>West Indies</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="12502522/7">Before the move could be completed Colonel Hay received notification that his regiment was to be disbanded and amalgamated with the<space/><link><target>53rd Regiment of Foot</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="12502522/8">As was traditional at that time (and still is with similar circumstance of the <link synthetic="true"><target>British Army</target></link>) there was much complaint and politicking, however whatever the circumstance of the infighting amongst <link synthetic="true"><target>Aberdeenshire</target></link> gentry,<space/><link><target>William Lamond Allardyce</target><part>Allardyce</part></link><space/>of Dunottar (<link synthetic="true"><target>Aberdeenshire</target></link>) in the<space/><link><target>House of Commons of Great Britain</target></link><space/>declared that <link synthetic="true"><target>Aberdeenshire</target></link> had no complaint with the amalgamation and this seemed to win the day over the support for the 109th by General Macleod.</sentence> <sentence id="12502522/9">On 12 September 1795 eighteen officers together with the muster of the 109th transferred to the 53rd Regiment ending the 109th <link synthetic="true"><target>Aberdeenshire</target></link> <link synthetic="true"><target>109th (Aberdeenshire) Regiment of Foot</target><part>Regiment of Foot</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence id="12502522/10"><link type="external" href="http://www.regiments.org/regiments/uk/inf/109-794.htm">Aberdeenshire Regiment of Foot</link>, regiments.org</sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="12502522/11"><link type="external" href="http://www.leinster-regiment-association.org.uk/history/18th/109th.htm">109 Regiment of Foot</link>; Regimental Association of the Prince of Wales's Leinster Regiment</sentence></listitem></list><paragraph><sentence id="12502522/12"><link><target>Category:Infantry regiments of the British Army</target></link><link><target>Category:Military units and formations established in 1794</target></link><link><target>Category:1795 disestablishments</target></link></sentence></paragraph></section>
