<param name="Current_members"/>
<param name="Past_members">Steve Verwolf<xhtml:br xmlns:xhtml=""/>Christopher Blue<xhtml:br xmlns:xhtml=""/>Paul Solger<xhtml:br xmlns:xhtml=""/><link><target>Duff McKagan</target></link><xhtml:br xmlns:xhtml=""/><link><target>Greg Gilmore</target></link><xhtml:br xmlns:xhtml=""/>David Garrigues<xhtml:br xmlns:xhtml=""/><link><target>Daniel House</target></link><xhtml:br xmlns:xhtml=""/>Jim Lightfoot</param>
</template><sentence id="9618419/0"><bold>10 <link synthetic="true"><target>10 Minute Warning</target><part>Minute Warning</part></link></bold><space/>(also known as<space/><bold>Ten <link synthetic="true"><target>10 Minute Warning</target><part>Minute Warning</part></link></bold>) was a<space/><link><target>hardcore punk</target></link><space/>band from<space/><link><target>Seattle</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Washington (U.S. state)</target><part>Washington</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/1">They became famous locally as one of the first bands to adapt the popular<space/><link><target>punk rock</target><part>punk</part></link><space/>sound to something slower and heavier, paving the way for<space/><link><target>grunge</target></link><space/>bands like<space/><link><target>Green River (band)</target><part>Green River</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Mother Love Bone</target></link><extension extension_name="ref" name="AMG"><template name="cite web">
<param name="url"><template name="Allmusic">
<param name="class">artist</param>
<param name="id">p294177/biography</param>
<param name="pure_url">yes</param>
</template></param>
<param name="title">10 Minute Warning > Biography</param>
<param name="publisher"><italics><link><target>Allmusic</target></link></italics></param>
<param name="accessdate">Mar. 11, 2010</param>
</template><template name="cite web">
<param name="url"><template name="Allmusic">
<param name="class">artist</param>
<param name="id">p294177/biography</param>
<param name="pure_url">yes</param>
</template></param>
<param name="title">10 Minute Warning > Biography</param>
<param name="publisher"><italics><link><target>Allmusic</target></link></italics></param>
<param name="accessdate">Mar. 11, 2010</param>
</template></extension><extension extension_name="ref" name="multiref1"><link type="external" href="http://www.duffmckagans-rawpower.com/bands_tmw.php">Duff McKagan's RAW POWER - Official Fanclub</link></extension><space/>before breaking up in 1984.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="AMG"/></paragraph></section>
<section></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="9618419/2">The group was formed in 1982, by<space/><link><target>The Fartz</target></link><space/>members Paul <link synthetic="true"><target>Solger</target></link> and<space/><link><target>Duff McKagan</target></link>, also of the<space/><link><target>Fastbacks</target></link>, after original <link synthetic="true"><target>The Fartz</target><part>Fartz</part></link> singer Blaine Cook quit due to musical differences.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/3">Filling out the band's line-up were vocalist Steve Verwolf, bassist David Garrigues, and future<space/><link><target>Mother Love Bone</target></link><space/>drummer,<space/><link><target>Greg Gilmore</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/4">David left the band in 83 due to personality clashes.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/5"><link synthetic="true"><target>Duff McKagan</target><part>Duff</part></link> took over duties on bass for a single 8 track recording of Necropolitan Affair.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/6"><link synthetic="true"><target>Duff McKagan</target><part>Duff</part></link> left the band in mid 84 due to - again - personality clashes.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/7">Jim Lightfoot, former partner in Modern Productions and member of Memory, joined as bass player, though stayed on only through a single performance.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/8">The final pre-<link><target>Sub Pop</target></link><space/>line up was cemented by the addition of<space/><link><target>Daniel House</target></link><space/>on bass.</sentence><space/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="9618419/9">Despite gaining a lot of criticism from the punk rock purists of the area, the bands performances are generally regarded as legendary, with rumours of psychedelic elements which caused<space/><link><target>Black Flag (band)</target><part>Black Flag</part></link>'s<space/><link><target>Henry Rollins</target></link><space/>to label them the "punk rock<space/><link><target>Hawkwind</target></link>",<extension extension_name="ref" name="multiref1"/>,<space/><link><target>Pearl Jam</target></link>'s<space/><link><target>Stone Gossard</target></link><space/>has credited them as the band that inspired him to learn guitar<extension extension_name="ref" name="multiref1"/><space/>It is perhaps not surprising then that the first of <link synthetic="true"><target>Stone Gossard</target><part>Gossard's</part></link> bands to gain recognition -<space/><link><target>Green River (band)</target><part>Green River</part></link><space/>- used the same grinding, slowed-down, punk rock riffage.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph>10 <sentence id="9618419/10"><link synthetic="true"><target>10 Minute Warning</target><part>Minute Warning</part></link> made numerous attempts at recording, most notably with<space/><link><target>Jello Biafra</target></link>'s 'Alternative Tentacles label and in 1984 they recorded what was to be their first album, which included the songs "Last Dream", "Again", "Life", "Stooge", "Necropolitan Affair", "Echoes", "Disraeli", "Heaven", "Woke Up Dreaming" and "Memories Gather Dust".</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/11">They also recorded a version of Pink Floyd's "The Nile Song"<extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://hem.bredband.net/jarmo/tmw/">Disconnected: An unofficial Ten Minute Warning Home Page</link></extension><space/>but the album was never released.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/12">At the time the <link synthetic="true"><target>Seattle</target></link> music industry was still young, and the indie labels which helped propel bands from that area into stardom in later years had yet to come into fruition.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/13">It is for this reason that Ten <link synthetic="true"><target>10 Minute Warning</target><part>Minute Warning</part></link> never released any recorded material before they split in<space/><link><target>1984</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/14">Which left the likes of<space/><link><target>Green River (band)</target><part>Green River</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Soundgarden</target></link><space/>to become known as the founders of what later became known as "<link><target>grunge</target></link>".</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="9618419/15">In 1984, following the farewell performance at the Lincoln Arts Center in <link synthetic="true"><target>Seattle</target></link>, the band members went their separate ways.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="AMG"/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="9618419/16">Paul left for New York with The Fags.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/17">He also later played in a band called Meddaphysical.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/18"><link synthetic="true"><target>Duff McKagan</target><part>Duff</part></link> and <link synthetic="true"><target>Greg Gilmore</target><part>Greg</part></link> moved to<space/><link><target>Los Angeles</target></link>, Steve went to San Francisco with <link synthetic="true"><target>Duff McKagan</target><part>Duff</part></link>, hoping to secure a gig singing for The <link synthetic="true"><target>Black Flag (band)</target><part>Black</part></link> Athletes, but returned after two weeks and resumed an ongoing struggle with drug addiction, which eventually found him divorced entirely from the music scene, until 1991 when he teamed up briefly with Steve Weid (<link><target>Tad (band)</target><part>Tad</part></link>) and Scott Wade (Sledge) in an early version of<space/><link><target>Foil (band)</target><part>Foil</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/19"><link synthetic="true"><target>Greg Gilmore</target><part>Greg</part></link> quickly became disillusioned with the LA scene and returned to<space/><link><target>Seattle</target></link><space/>and eventually joined<space/><link><target>Mother Love Bone</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/20"><link synthetic="true"><target>Duff McKagan</target><part>Duff</part></link> however remained in LA and joined rock band<space/><link><target>Guns N' Roses</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="AMG"/></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="9618419/21"><link synthetic="true"><target>Duff McKagan</target><part>Duff</part></link> left <link synthetic="true"><target>Guns N' Roses</target></link> in 1997 and moved back to <link synthetic="true"><target>Seattle</target></link>,<extension extension_name="ref" name="AMG"/><space/>where he met with many of his old friends, including <link synthetic="true"><target>Stone Gossard</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/22">It was him telling them how great they used to be, that encouraged the members of Ten <link synthetic="true"><target>10 Minute Warning</target><part>Minute Warning</part></link> to reunite that year, with new vocalist Christopher Blue<extension extension_name="ref" name="AMG"/><space/>replacing Steve Verwolf, who was serving a term in Federal Prison.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/23">It was at this time that the band finally recorded a self-titled album on well known <link synthetic="true"><target>Seattle</target></link> label <link synthetic="true"><target>Sub Pop</target></link><extension extension_name="ref" name="AMG"/><space/>- nine tracks including two new versions of songs originally recorded by<space/><link><target>The Fartz</target></link><space/>(Is This The Way? and Buried), and also the original version of Mezz, which was later re-recorded for <link synthetic="true"><target>Duff McKagan</target><part>Duff's</part></link> unreleased solo album, Beautiful Disease.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="9618419/24">The album was eventually released in 1998.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref" name="AMG"/><space/><sentence id="9618419/25">However, by this time Paul <link synthetic="true"><target>Solger</target></link> had quit due to "musical differences".</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/26">Ten <link synthetic="true"><target>10 Minute Warning</target><part>Minute Warning</part></link> played its last show on August 22, 1998 at the Roseland theater in<space/><link><target>Portland, Oregon</target></link>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://gilmore.freeshell.org/page.html">One Arm Waving</link></extension><space/><sentence id="9618419/27">Since then, <link synthetic="true"><target>Duff McKagan</target><part>Duff</part></link> has reunited with his former <link synthetic="true"><target>Guns N' Roses</target></link> band mates<space/><link><target>Slash (musician)</target><part>Slash</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Matt Sorum</target></link><space/>to form<space/><link><target>Velvet Revolver</target></link>, and Paul <link synthetic="true"><target>Solger</target></link> was diagnosed with and successfully treated for cancer in 2004.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/28">As of 2008, he resides in Eastern <link synthetic="true"><target>Washington (U.S. state)</target><part>Washington</part></link> with his parents.</sentence> <sentence id="9618419/29">Steve Verwolf died of a heroin overdose in August, 2008.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><list type="bullet"><listitem><sentence id="9618419/30">Steve Verwolf ??vocals<space/><xhtml:small xmlns:xhtml="">(1982??984)</xhtml:small></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="9618419/31">Christopher Blue ??vocals<space/><xhtml:small xmlns:xhtml="">(1997??998)</xhtml:small></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="9618419/32">Paul <link synthetic="true"><target>Solger</target></link> ??lead guitar<space/><xhtml:small xmlns:xhtml="">(1982??984, 1997??998)</xhtml:small></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="9618419/33"><link><target>Duff McKagan</target></link><space/>??guitar<space/><xhtml:small xmlns:xhtml="">(1982??984, 1997??998)</xhtml:small></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="9618419/34">David Garrigues ??bass<space/><xhtml:small xmlns:xhtml="">(1982??983, 1997??998)</xhtml:small></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="9618419/35">Jim Lightfoot ??bass<space/><xhtml:small xmlns:xhtml="">(1983)</xhtml:small></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="9618419/36"><link><target>Daniel House</target></link><space/>??bass<space/><xhtml:small xmlns:xhtml="">(1983??984)</xhtml:small></sentence></listitem><listitem><sentence id="9618419/37"><link><target>Greg Gilmore</target></link><space/>??drums, percussion<space/><xhtml:small xmlns:xhtml="">(1982??984, 1997??998)</xhtml:small></sentence></listitem></list></section>

<section><paragraph><template name="Politics of the Philippines">\n</template><sentence id="11135163/0">The<space/><bold>Tenth <link synthetic="true"><target>10th Philippine Legislature</target><part>Philippine Legislature</part></link></bold><space/>was the meeting of the<space/><link><target>legislature</target></link><space/>of the<space/><link><target>Philippines</target></link><space/>under the sovereign control of the<space/><link><target>United States</target></link><space/>from 1934 to 1935.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><template name="Unreferenced">\n<param name="date">March 2010</param>\n</template><sentence id="7826499/0"><bold>11 <link synthetic="true"><target>11 Freunde</target><part>Freunde</part></link></bold><space/>(<link><target>german language</target><part>German</part></link><space/>for<space/><italics>11 friends</italics>) is a<space/><link><target>Germany</target><part>German</part></link><space/><link><target>sport</target><trail>s</trail></link><space/><link><target>magazine</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="7826499/1">The magazine, founded in 2000 by Reinaldo Coddou H. and Philipp K?ster.</sentence> <sentence id="7826499/2">It is published monthly in<space/><link><target>Berlin</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="7826499/3">The magazine's name was inspired by a quote from a soccer tactics book by<space/><link><target>Richard Girulatis</target></link><space/>(1920): "Elf (11) <link synthetic="true"><target>11 Freunde</target><part>Freunde</part></link> m?sst ihr sein, wenn ihr Siege wollt erringen", which can be translated as<space/><italics>if you want to win, you have to be eleven friends</italics>.</sentence></paragraph></section>

</template></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="27733785/0">The<space/><bold>120th <link synthetic="true"><target>Mansfield, Ohio</target><part>Ohio</part></link> Volunteer <link synthetic="true"><target>120th Ohio Infantry</target><part>Infantry</part></link></bold><space/>(or<space/><bold>120th OVI</bold>) was an<space/><link><target>infantry</target></link><space/><link><target>regiment</target></link><space/>in the<space/><link><target>Union Army</target></link><space/>during the<space/><link><target>American Civil War</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="27733785/1">The 120th <link synthetic="true"><target>120th Ohio Infantry</target><part>Ohio Infantry</part></link> was organized<space/><link><target>Mansfield, Ohio</target></link><space/>and mustered in August 29, 1862 for three years service under the command of<space/><link><target>Colonel (United States)</target><part>Colonel</part></link><space/>Daniel French.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="27733785/2">The regiment first served unattached,<space/><link><target>Army of Kentucky</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Department of the Ohio</target></link>, to November 1862.</sentence> 1st <sentence id="27733785/3">Brigade, 9th Division, Right Wing,<space/><link><target>XIII Corps (Union Army)</target><part>XIII Corps</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Department of the Tennessee</target></link>, to December 1862.</sentence> 1st <sentence id="27733785/4">Brigade, 3rd Division, Sherman's Yazoo Expedition, to January 1863.</sentence> 1st <sentence id="27733785/5">Brigade, 9th Division, <link synthetic="true"><target>XIII Corps (Union Army)</target><part>XIII Corps</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Army of the Tennessee</target></link>, to July 1863.</sentence> 3rd <sentence id="27733785/6">Brigade, 1st Division, <link synthetic="true"><target>XIII Corps (Union Army)</target><part>XIII Corps</part></link>, <link synthetic="true"><target>Department of the Tennessee</target></link>, to August 1863, and<space/><link><target>Department of the Gulf</target></link><space/>to November 1863.</sentence> <sentence id="27733785/7">Plaquemine, Louisiana, District of Baton Rouge, Louisiana, <link synthetic="true"><target>Department of the Gulf</target></link>, to March 1864.</sentence> 2nd <sentence id="27733785/8">Brigade, 1st Division, <link synthetic="true"><target>XIII Corps (Union Army)</target><part>XIII Corps</part></link>, to June 1864.</sentence> 2nd <sentence id="27733785/9">Brigade, 3rd Division,<space/><link><target>XIX Corps (Union Army)</target><part>XIX Corps</part></link>, <link synthetic="true"><target>Department of the Gulf</target></link>, to August 1864.</sentence> 2nd <sentence id="27733785/10">Brigade, 2nd Division, <link synthetic="true"><target>XIX Corps (Union Army)</target><part>XIX Corps</part></link>, to November 1864.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="27733785/11">The 120th <link synthetic="true"><target>120th Ohio Infantry</target><part>Ohio Infantry</part></link> ceased to exist on November 25, 1864 due to consolidation with the<space/><link><target>114th Ohio Infantry</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="27733785/12">Moved to Cincinnati, <link synthetic="true"><target>Mansfield, Ohio</target><part>Ohio</part></link>, October 25; then to Covington, Ky., and duty there until November 24.</sentence> <sentence id="27733785/13">Moved to Memphis, Tenn.</sentence>, <sentence id="27733785/14">November 24-December 7, 1862.</sentence> <sentence id="27733785/15">Sherman's <section><paragraph><sentence id="31505426/2">Since its d?but in June 2005, 123RF.com hosts over 9,000,000 stock photographs and vector illustrations featuring various genres and themes with over 35,000 contributing photographers and illustrators.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://www.123rf.com/">123RF.com</link><space/>; Stats released on image website</extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="31505426/3">In year 2010, 123RF.com relaunched its website that offers faster response plus a modernized and sleeker interface furnished with several added features.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/4">A mobile-enabled website was also created to cater to clients who own an iPhone, iPod or other 3G enabled device.</sentence><space/><extension extension_name="ref" name="StockPhotoTalk 3-31-2010"><preblock><preline><link type="external" href="http://www.stockphototalk.com/the_stock_photo_industry_/2010/03/123rfcom-launches-new-website-with-many-exciting-features-.html">"123RF.com Launches New Website with many Exciting Features"</link>, StockPhotoTalk, March 31, 2010</preline></preblock></extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="31505426/5">The stock images available on 123RF.com are provided by contributing photographers and illustrators.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/6">Contributors can register for a free account with 123RF.com and submit their work.</sentence><space/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="31505426/7">Apart from providing<space/><link><target>Stock_photos</target><part>stock images</part></link>, 123RF.com is also an online community for designers and photographers to share their ideas through blog posts and interviews.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/8">The site features a<space/><link><target>Adobe Photoshop</target><part>Photoshop Tutorial</part></link><space/>contributed by experienced designers with tutorials ranging from intermediate to difficult levels.</sentence> 123RF.com also offers <sentence id="31505426/9"><link synthetic="true"><target>Stock_photos</target><part>Image</part></link> Enlargement services<space/><extension extension_name="ref" name="StockPhotoTalk 3-31-2010"><preblock><preline><link type="external" href="http://www.stockphototalk.com/the_stock_photo_industry_/2010/03/123rfcom-launches-new-website-with-many-exciting-features-.html">"123RF.com Launches New Website with many Exciting Features"</link>, StockPhotoTalk, March 31, 2010</preline></preblock></extension><space/>to its clients.</sentence><space/></paragraph><paragraph>123RF.com supports 12 major languages and it can be viewed in<space/><sentence id="31505426/10"><link><target>English language</target><part>English</part></link>,<space/><link><target>German language</target><part>German</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Spanish language</target><part>Spanish</part></link>,<space/><link><target>French language</target><part>French</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Italian language</target><part>Italian</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Simplified Chinese language</target><part>Simplified Chinese</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Traditional Chinese language</target><part>Traditional Chinese</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Dutch language</target><part>Dutch</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Czech language</target><part>Czech</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Polish language</target><part>Polish</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Russian language</target><part>Russian</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Japanese language</target><part>Japanese</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Korean language</target><part>Korean</part></link>.</sentence></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="31505426/11"><link synthetic="true"><target>Stock_photos</target><part>Images</part></link> of 123RF.com are licensed through credit or subscription packages.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/12">Credit offer users ??ay-as-you-go??convenience while subscriptions provide affordable downloads for organizations that require fresh images on a daily basis.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/13">Files can be downloaded immediately, and used in almost any applications.</sentence><space/></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="31505426/14">At the same time, subscribers of 123RF.com get to utilize the Corporate <link synthetic="true"><target>stock photography</target><part>Stock</part></link> Intranet (CSI) System.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/15">CSI allow users to organize, manage and keep track of image downloads through a personalized website.</sentence><space/><extension extension_name="ref" name="Stock Index Online 5-30-2008"><preblock><preline><link type="external" href="http://www.stockindexonline.com/index.php?q=IndustryNews&amp;id_new=2124">"Get into the Intranet"</link>, Stock Index Online, May 30, 2008</preline></preblock></extension></paragraph><paragraph><sentence id="31505426/16">All approved images are uploaded to the searchable online database.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/17"><link synthetic="true"><target>Stock_photos</target><part>Images</part></link> cost between 1 and 470 credits, depending on size and image collection (with credits ranging from $.21 to $1.00 USD each)<extension extension_name="ref" name="Photobuyer Guide 8-22-2010"><preblock><preline><link type="external" href="http://www.photobuyerguide.com/page/123rf/">"123RF Review"</link>, Photobuyer Guide, August 22, 2010</preline></preblock></extension><space/><extension extension_name="ref"><link type="external" href="http://www.123rf.com/islogin_globalv4.1.php?is_islogin_credits=1">Purchase Credits and Subscibe</link><space/>; Pricing information</extension>.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/18"><link synthetic="true"><target>Stock_photos</target><part>Image</part></link> size starts from Small up to 300MB TIFF (XXXL).</sentence> 123RF.com also markets vector graphics made in programs such as<space/><sentence id="31505426/19"><link><target>Adobe Illustrator</target></link><space/>or<space/><link><target>Macromedia Freehand</target></link>; or image editors like<space/><link><target>Adobe Photoshop</target></link>.</sentence></paragraph><paragraph>123RF.com accepts transactions in major currencies like the<space/><sentence id="31505426/20"><link><target>United States dollar</target><part>US Dollar</part></link>,<space/><link><target>British Pound</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Euro</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Japanese Yen</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Australian Dollar</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Canadian Dollar</target></link>,<space/><link><target>Czech koruna</target><part>Czech Koruna</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Renminbi</target><part>Renminbi</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Korean Won</target><part>Korean Won</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Hong Kong Dollar</target><part>Hong Kong Dollar</part></link>,<space/><link><target>Singapore Dollar</target><part>Singapore Dollar</part></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Malaysian Ringgit</target></link>.</sentence><space/></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="31505426/21">Contributors can apply by uploading their work through the website.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/22">The applicant must supply keywords and submit them to the 123RF.com inspection queue, where each and every image is examined and reviewed to ensure that it meets the standards of quality, marketability as well as the copyright and trademark laws.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/23">Once approved, contributors can begin uploading their work through the website.</sentence> <sentence id="31505426/24">The contributor will enjoy a 50% revenue from every credit image downloaded and flat rate of 36? for subscription downloads.</sentence><space/><extension extension_name="ref" name="DPZ-01-03-11"><preblock><preline><link type="external" href="http://www.digitalpicturezone.com/digital-imaging/make-money-with-your-photo-skill-via-123rf-com/">"Make Money with Your Photo Skill via 123RF.com"</link>,<space/><italics>Digital Picture Zone</italics>, Mar 1, 2011</preline></preblock></extension><extension extension_name="ref" name="Blogging Secret 3-21-11"><preblock><preline><link type="external" href="http://www.blogging-secret.com/9-places-to-sell-your-photos-make-money-online">"9 Places to Sell Your Photos ??Make Money Online"</link>, Blogging Secret, March 21, 2011</preline></preblock></extension><extension extension_name="ref" name="TS-02-04-10"><preblock><preline><link type="external" href="http://technologytosoftware.com/10-best-websites-to-sell-your-photos-online.html">"10 Best Websites To Sell Your Photos Online"</link>,<space/><italics>Technology to Software</italics>, April 2, 2010</preline></preblock></extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="16676659/0"><link><target>File:Geograph-1209044-by-John-Salmon.jpg</target><part>thumb</part><part>right</part><part>125 London Wall</part></link><bold>125 <link synthetic="true"><target>125 London Wall</target><part>London Wall</part></link></bold>, also known as<space/><bold>Alban Gate</bold>, is a<space/><link><target>Postmodern architecture</target><part>postmodernist</part></link><space/>building on<space/><link><target>London Wall#The modern road</target><part>London Wall</part></link><space/>in the<space/><link><target>City of London</target></link>,<space/><link><target>England</target></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="16676659/1">Along with<space/><link><target>Embankment Place</target></link><space/>and<space/><link><target>Vauxhall Cross</target></link>, it has been described as one of the three projects that established designer<space/><link><target>Terry Farrell (architect)</target><part>Sir Terry Farrell</part></link>'s reputation in the late 1980s / early 1990s.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="Cite web">
<param name="title">Terry Farrell and Partners</param>
<param name="2">RUDI - Resource for Urban Design Information</param>
<param name="publisher">Resource for Urban Design Information</param>
<param name="url">http://www.rudi.net/books/12042</param>
<param name="accessdate">2010-08-19</param>
</template><template name="Cite web">
<param name="title">Terry Farrell and Partners</param>
<param name="2">RUDI - Resource for Urban Design Information</param>
<param name="publisher">Resource for Urban Design Information</param>
<param name="url">http://www.rudi.net/books/12042</param>
<param name="accessdate">2010-08-19</param>
</template></extension><space/><sentence id="16676659/2">In 2004,<space/><link><target>Deyan Sudjic</target></link><space/>described it as 'Postmodernism at its most exuberant' placing it at number 5 in a list of 10 Triumphs of recent UK architecture.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="Cite news">
<param name="last">Sudjic</param>
<param name="first">Deyan</param>
<param name="authorlink">Deyan Sudjic</param>
<param name="title">Peace in our time</param>

<param name="date">2004-05-02</param>
<param name="url">http://www.guardian.co.uk/artanddesign/2004/may/02/architecture</param>
<param name="accessdate">2010-08-19</param>
</template><template name="Cite news">
<param name="last">Sudjic</param>
<param name="first">Deyan</param>
<param name="authorlink">Deyan Sudjic</param>
<param name="title">Peace in our time</param>
<param name="newspaper"><link><target>The Observer</target></link></param>
<param name="date">2004-05-02</param>
<param name="url">http://www.guardian.co.uk/artanddesign/2004/may/02/architecture</param>
<param name="accessdate">2010-08-19</param>
</template></extension></paragraph></section>

<section><paragraph><sentence id="16676659/3">It is composed of two distinct towers, set at a 90 degree angle to each other.</sentence> <sentence id="16676659/4">The developers negotiated the<space/><link><target>air rights</target></link><space/>to allow one tower to occupy the space above <link synthetic="true"><target>125 London Wall</target><part>London Wall</part></link>, the modern thoroughfare running along the perimeter of the<space/><link><target>Roman London</target><part>Roman City</part></link>.</sentence> <sentence id="16676659/5">The building's construction began in 1990, and was completed in 1992 with 18 floors and a maximum height of<space/><template name="Convert">
<param name="1">82</param>
<param name="2">m</param>
<param name="3">ft</param>
<param name="abbrv">on</param>
<param name="5">-1</param>
</template>.</sentence><extension extension_name="ref"><template name="Cite web">
